reviewText:
Early Access Review

BeamNG.drive is a very physics-heavy simulation, utilizing Torque3D and a very accurate, realistic soft-body physics engine. What does this mean for you, however? This game provides stunningly realistic vehicle deformations, much like Rigs of Rods, which BeamNG.drive is based off. BeamNG.drive tries to be the most accurate vehicle damaging simulator, and it is succeeding. While it is still only in Alpha, I strongly recommend picking this up if you're like me and find pleasure in smashing pickup trucks into small Japanese compact cars.

If you wish to own this title, you can order a Steam Alpha key at their website, http://www.beamng.com/

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a long, in-depth review, so bear with me. :P

This is an awesome simulator! You can do anything you want with cars. The base game comes with 11 worlds (aka terrains) to explore, and they range from 1 square kilometer to 2 square kilometers. The developers do, however make them seem much bigger despite their real size. There is also an infinite grid map which is completely flat and empty and the ground is nothing more than a grid.

Here are the vehicles included with BeamNG. When I say a car resembles another real-life one, you may or may not agree, OK?
Also in the base game are 14 fictional vehicles based off of real-life vehicles, which are FULLY customizable. You can customize everything from the color of the car to the design of the tailpipe. Currently there are 2 classic cars based off of American cars of the 1960's and 70's (Gavril Barstow and Bruckell Moonhawk), a super fast Italian car that is similar to a 1980's and 90's Ferrari (Civetta Bolide),  a boring to drive car (Ibishu Pessima) from the late 90's and early 2000s that is the equivalent of a Japanese mid-sized car such as the Toyota Corolla. There is also a somewhat modern pickup truck (Gavril D-15) that is Ford Ranger sized, a full-sized van for cargo (Gavril H-series) that is like the Ford E-series, a Chevy Tahoe-style SUV that shares much of the same parts as the D-15, a car that would be used for drifting (Ibishu 200BX) if it was real and has body curves like a Nissan 240SX, and finally an American full-sized car (Gavril Grand Marshal) that seems to resemble a Ford Crown Victoria and is commonly used as a police car. There are still some cars I didn't mention that are pretty interesting, so those are only some of the cars.

Anyway, enough about the content. Let's get into the gameplay and physics.

Although for now there is no Career mode, this simulator is still very fun to play. There are scenarios, and they are usually coordinated time trials on a specific course on a specific terrain. Sometimes it is just for fun, like jumping a van off a ramp and landing unscathed.

And the physics, oh they will not get any better than this. BeamNG is the most realistic and detailed vehicle simulator to date. It simulates the behavior of vehicles from the glass breaking to the hubcaps falling off. BeamNG uses a unique system for ultra-realistic vehicle behavior that yields a unique gaming experience each time. It uses beams (BEAMng) and nodes to simulate each and every part independently. The nodes connect all of the thousands of beams together, and the beams can deform, bend, and break. There are no predefined damage models. The node and beam system calculates the damage on any one section of the car. For example, if you slide past a wall in a Need For Speed game, with the front facing it slightly more than the back, the windows will probably shatter and then there will be paint scratches on random places of the car. Let's slide past that same wall in BeamNG. The mirror fell off and there is a dent in the front bumper EXACTLY where the car contacted the wall. Also a hubcap most likely fell off if the car had plastic rims.

If all that isn't enough, there is a big community on the BeamNG forums cranking out mods frequently. There are about 50 extra vehicles for download at the time of this writing and well over 75 terrains.

And, finally, let's talk customization. Let's take the D-15 for example. For this single vehicle, you can customize the paint job, the tow hitch, the type of engine (I6 or V8), supercharger, lights, color, bumper type and color, suspension, body, and even the light bar to name a few. So the bottom line is, this game offers more customization options than any other driving game currently on the market.

I hope this review was helpful to any new BeamNG players. Enjoy this wonderful game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Introduction
BeamNG.drive is a realistic soft-body physics simulator developed by BeamNG. BeamNG.drive not only lets you drive realistic cars, it also lets you crash them into each other! While the racing may not appeal to those who don’t use a wheel, the game’s awesome physics can be easily enjoyed using a gamepad or even a keyboard. It’s worth mentioning I’m in the camp of mainly crashing things into each other so I won’t focus so much on anything more heavily related to racing.

While I’ve only recently received the game I have been following its progress for around a year and it has received regular updates during that time. Obviously it’s still not a finished product but what’s already in the game is good and if the devs continue working on the game it’s only going to get better.

Full Disclosure: A review copy was provided by the developer.

Presentation
As you’d expect from a realistic simulator, it’s a good looking game. Of course it’s not to the point of being photo-realistic but everything looks good enough in the game to make it feel about as real as a simulator can be. The UI and menus are absolutely spot on for the game, the speedometer is usually the only visible UI element and it’s only visible when you’re using the third person camera, it’s out of the way otherwise which certainly helps your driving if you’re just smashing things into each other. The menus are simple and easy to use and even when you’re using the menu you can still see most of the screen (which is good because you’ll occasionally want to be editing your option while playing the game, for example if you want to increase gravity while you’re mid-air to utterly obliterate your car).

Gameplay
BeamNG.drive’s two (current) game modes are Scenarios and Free Roam with a Career mode coming soon. The Scenario game mode features pre-made scenarios from the developers themselves as well as any user made scenarios that you download from the BeamNG website. Generally these scenarios are either races or car tests but some of them are a little more exciting (not to say the others aren’t fun) such as scenarios where you drive a police car and you have to stop a speeding vehicle. The Free Roam mode is pretty much self-explanatory, you can choose one of the game’s eleven maps with any of the game’s thirteen vehicles. You can also use other in-game objects here too like a giant hamster wheel or a canon. Free Roam is where you’ll be making your own scenarios if you’re so inclined but as far as I can tell you need the Scenario editing mod from the website to do this. But if you don’t want to make your own scenarios it can be a lot of fun to just drive your car around one of the Island maps or smash it into things in the gridmap full of ramps and other fun things.

Realism
Realism is of course the most important part of a simulation game and, as far as I can tell, BeamNG.drive is pretty realistic. Now it is worth mentioning that I don’t drive and I’ve never seen a real car crash but I reckon I’ve got enough experience as a passenger and as someone who has a decent knowledge of physics to comment on this aspect of the game.

Of course it’s hard to tell when playing with a gamepad rather than a wheel but vehicle handling seems pretty solid. As far as I know there’s no traction control for the vehicles in the game so things do get a little bit skiddy from time to time but the cars all feel pretty weighty (apart from the three wheel Pigeon of course). The soft body physics are out of this world good, I don’t think I’ve come across a game with better. Obviously slamming things into each other looks good but it’s when you misjudge a corner and go head on into a tree that you really see just how powerful the engine is.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=569607633

Miscellaneous When in Free Roam you have control over environmental variables such as time of day and gravity and in both Free Roam and Scenarios you’re able to slow down time up to 100x.
All thirteen vehicles have several different pre-made configurations but you can customize the cars with parts and paint jobs as well as then save whatever you make to be used in future.
The game ran really well for me despite the fact that I have a pretty weak GPU.
There’s not a huge amount of ‘defined’ content right now so if you’re not the kind of person who can make their own fun in a sandbox game then you may wish to hit the follow button instead of buying the game for the time being. Just to be clear, there’s probably a good few hours of scenarios
The engine sounds didn’t sound too realistic to me but that may just be from a lack of car knowledge rather than the sounds being unrealistic. It turns out that these sound effects are simply placeholders for the time being. The crashing sound effects are reasonably good but if you’re hitting things for a prolonged period of time it seems the sound effects are only audible from time to time rather than every time there’s a collision.
While the vehicles in the game aren’t ‘real’ makes and models they are all based on real vehicles.
Verdict
Worth Purchasing.  (If you like Sandbox physics games)

BeamNG.drive may be lacking in 'defined' content but it more than makes up for it with its incredibly realistic soft body physics and good graphics. If you want a realistic driving sim or you just want to crash things into each other then chances are you’ll enjoy this game!

No drama, Just Reviews.

El K.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A review is nothing if it isn't helpful, so let's get down to brass tacks. At the moment, you should know BeamNG is not a game.  It's at best a sandbox title with most of the necessary content missing.  Its far better to say at the moment that its a game engine looking for a game.  But what a game engine ...

The content, as it stands, offers you the chance to drive round a handful of locations.  Thanks to Johnny3600 who points out that this game uses Torque3D as an engine, not the CryEngine as I first thought (though the backgrounds are very Far Cry - think tropical, vegetation, poorish roads), but critically are quite large and varied.  So you can expect well-made tarmacked roads to ring islands, with grotty little dirt tracks in the centre often leading to ledges, mountains etc.  The vehicles are mostly regular cars (I believe generic models), including pickups and a Rig.  Don't expect forumula 1 cars, this is a far more everyday selection of vehicles.

So far it all sounds uninspiring.  What makes it so good?  Well, the physics engine effectively makes it a crash simulator.  Every piece of each car is detailed to give it form, bendableness, weight and mass, etc.  When assembled they work as a real car would, but when you come into contact with something they all crush, get displaced and generally smash up most convincingly.  On its own its not enough to make a car game, but when its combined with a very satisfying feeling of driving you have a potential monster hit.

In a word, what we have here is the beauty of mathematics, cutting edge in all its glory, put to use to smash things up.  It's fantastic, rewarding, enormous fun to drive, and best of all utterly convincing.  I've crashed enough in this game to know that you don't want to fishtail and clip the rear of your car if you're going to crash in real life because the loss of control is horrendous (as in how a certain English ex-Princess met her fate).  You stand a far better chance of survival just going head on with an object despite the g-forces (with a seatbelt, of course.)

Trust me, the first time you crash a car in this game, the sense of emotional trauma in the silence that follows is palpable.

So there it is.  A few cars, some nice locations, and nothing to do.  All dressed up and nowhere to go.  I'm not even sure that anyone knows exactly how it will all end up when it finally becomes a game.  There are experiments with car chases, and there's always the prospect of multiplayer, but frankly it doesn't lend itself to the usual genres of car games.  You just have to buy it on faith at the moment, but its still immensely enjoyable.

Crazikyle points out that there are lots of MODs available right now and for many people this is a deal breaker.  I'm no expert on MODs, so by all means anyone who has some to recommend should add them to the bottom of the review in the comments section.  I want to make this review as helpful as possible, and if you folks can help do that by contributing suggestions then please go right ahead and do so.

One more thought to leave you with: I've played some excellent racing games including iRacer, Project Cars, Assetto Corsa, etc.  None of them feel like you are driving an organic, real-world machine quite the way that BeamNG does.  The cars in BeamNG are made of assembled pieces, and the pieces shake and rattle and bounce under the torque and forces just like a real car.  Other developers  'pretend' their cars are real by suggesting movement and bounce, but only BeamNG has the sense that you have a real, honest-to-God vehicle glued to your throttle pedal.

If that isn't enough to pique your interest, may I suggest a nice game of Scrabble?

The off-road handling is fantastic with a wheel. In my mind, this game is the spiritual successor to the original 1nsane. I highly recommend it to anyone who likes driving off-road, and has an FFB wheel laying around. You dont need a G27 to enjoy the game, even a $50 Driving Force Pro would work great with it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Perfect game for any car fan, regardless of age.

There's not a whole lot of fancy graphics, no lens flares, relatively simple smoke/dust effects, most foliage (except trees) are made of flat textures (which are pretty well done, you can't really tell unless you stop and zoom right in on the grass, looks fine if you're driving even at low speeds), and the shaders aren't modified to give a 'cinematic look'. So this game isn't an astonishingly pretty game. But you know what, that's okay.

Each vehicle is intricately modelled, down to the point where you can see each individual part of the engine. You can see the butterfly valves on your supercharged V8 muscle car, you can see the engine block move around in its mounts slightly as you rev the engine. The level of detail is insane. Hit a harsh bump that bottoms out your custom, lowered car? Be prepared to potentially have your entire exhaust system ripped out of your car. Hit a sharp kerb at high speed? Might wanna watch your tires, they can pop, giving your car an unnatural feel. The physical damage in this game is brutally realistic, as each car is not 'hard-coded' with performance stats, health points, etc. Each INDIVIDUAL PART of a car makes up it's whole performance, much like a real car. Pop your front-right tire, and your car will start veering slightly to the right. Fit sport tires, you might be able to handle a corner slightly faster. Lower your suspension, you'll reduce body rolls and keep all 4 tires on the road better, resulting in better grip.
It goes on and on. The soft-body physics overall are brilliant, the cars crumple, wobble, and react exactly how you'd expect a car to react.

Maps:

The maps that come with the game are very nice, and quite varied.
Gridmap: A testing map, with an assortment of jumps, surface types (from sand and dirt to mud and water), slalom cones, objects to crash into and a few high-speed race courses.

Port: A small map set on a port, a perfect map for Gymkhana or drifting fans, with all kinds of shipping containers, warehouses, and a few ramps along with it.

Industrial Site: A medium sized map set on a seaside industrial area, it features a RallyCross track with multiple configurations, an offroad racing track laced with thick mud that will bog down your average rally car, but take a big 4x4 and you'll plow straight on through, and a more traditional tarmac race course. The industrial area also features many warehouses like the Port map, and a nice little circuit that races around it, featuring a jump over a small inlet.

East Coast USA: Set in the East Coast of the USA (As the nae suggests), it has a medium-sized town, along with fairly well maintained roads, that go from the coast to snaking through the forest. Lots of dirt trails through fields and woodlands for rallying around too.

Jungle Rock Island: On a Tropical Island, this map has poorly-maintained roads that call for terrifying high-speed driving along the coastline of this island. It also has many offroad dirt trails that run through the forest, and can quite easily end up getting you lost! There's also a few little rally trails, and industrial areas, quarries, and a port. Probably my favourite map.

Cliff: Spawns you in at the top of a cliff, the only way around is down the cliff. Fun little map for just throwing stuff of cliffs and watching it arrive at the bottom as a mangled mess. Not much to the map other than that, but still fun nonetheless.

Hirochi Raceway: A race-focused map, this raceway is GP-styled, with very wide, smooth corners, along with fast straights and chicanes thrown in. This map also has a few forest routes, that can take you on a narrow road through some forests, so any mistakes can be fatal.So, quite a few maps, with lots of variety.

Scenarios

The game has a wide variety of scenarios, too many to list here, that cover multiple fun aspects of the game.

These can range from tutorials, to shakedowns of various cars, police chases, races, delivery challenges, even a 'hyper-miling' challenge where you have to cross Jungle Rock Island with very little gas left in your car. There's even a demolition derby scenario for people to 'party play'.


Overall, I'd give this game a 8/10, I'd like to see networked multiplayer (something the BeamNG devs might implement if their engine can support it) and a campaign mode (which the devs have planned pretty much since day 1 of the project)

Lots more potential, the modding community is great, who make new maps, scenarios, vehicles, etc, etc.

Definitely worth the buy, especially for car fans, IMO.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

// BeamNG.drive is a 3D Racing Simulator: //
// Schuitje82 - Extended Review //

When I made this review the game had been released in Early Access.
There is no influence from the maker due to a free key or any other reasons.

Title: BeamNG.drive
Genre: Race, Simulator,
Developer: BeamNG
Release date: 29 mei 2015 (Early Access)


Why I wanted it, and maybe you will too?
===============================
Personally I love race / car simulator video games.
If it's a racing game like Forza or a Sandbox simulator I want to play them all.
I've watched some movies and reviews about this game and wanted to know for myself what this game is all about.
Yes it's a simulator and oh yeah.... you can crash your car and it’sreally AWESOME!
Still, I wanted to try it myself and make a review about it.


Core Gameplay:
============
This is a pure simulator, so if you are looking for a racing game, maybe this is also something for you.
You have some different modes to choose from, like Scenarios such as Freeroaming.
Scenarios are  for the people who like to have a goal while they play around with the simulator.
I must say there are really very many modes made for you to try.
For example: Road Race, Jumps, Full Circuit Racing, Rally Croos Long Courses, Destruction Derby (multiplayer) and much more!
The Free roaming is really cool for the player who likes to drive around the levels the Dev's made for us.
You can choose already from 10 massive levels that you can drive and play through with all the cars that are ready to pickup from the car list.
If you think, “What kind of levels?’ for example:
You can choose from giant cliff, Derby Arena, Small Island, USA; and East Cost, USA as a Raceway to go high speed.
So these modes give you many hours of fun and in the future they will add campaigns for more ways to play.
Last option and I think the coolest is the Add Content" option.
What makes this game really cool is that you can add your own levels and mods to it that other people have built for us.
Check the MOD section on the online website to see all the crazy and cool things other people have made for this awesome game.

http://www.beamng.com/resources/?ingame=2

I geot excited after every page seeing what all people have made for this great sanbox simulator !!


Graphics:
========
The first thing that makes this a nice simulator is the graphical part. (In my opinion.)
Everything looks really amazing and that was the first thing i noticed about the game that made me want to try it.
Not only the roads
date: but even the tree's a looking amazing. What appeals to me most is the car detail!\nFor example the car interior
hoursPlayed: and everything else looks really amazing
voteText: .\naAnd let’s not forget about the damage that can be done to your car!\nIf you crash into a tree
helpfulPercent: your car’s hood folds like a piece of paper.\nI think they did a really great job with this aspect of the game!\nThe onOnly thing I think is annoying sometimes: with a small crash even when there isn’t any huge physical damage
votesHelpful:
your car can get stuck and not be moved / driven.


Controls:
=======
I played the game with my keayboard as well as my Xbox 360 Wireless controller.
I can recommend the controller because you have more feeling with it.
For example
votesTotal: make sure to remember that  when you take a turn
votesFunny: sometimes your car brakes out and with a controller it is much easier to control and recover the car.\nI'm happy with the dev's choice for controller support because many games I play in early access does not support this.\nThe cars feltels really weird in the beginning when I played the game
commentsCount: only after some time did I get used to it.\nEvery car feels slightly different
column16: which and still makes it fun to play and try every car that I can choosice from.\nThey did a really good job with the different roads

likeand I mean is whean you go offroad racing.


Multiplayer:
=========
Still this is a early access game
column18: but there are some crazy co-op local co-op things to do.\nLike destructiiton derby

column20:
so we can all drive all together!.


Overall:
======
This a really fun and well madegood and fun Car simulator where  you can have hours of fun!.
TheGame game wais only released infrom 2015 and there are allready so many community mods we can try out!.
It's a nice project with very much potential to it.... so Dev's keep up the good work.

I give this Simulator a 9/10 score.
A job well done !!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWhat truly sets BeamNG apart from other vehicle games is how the vehicles are ALWAYS responding to forces acting upon them. In most vehicle games, damage is a scripted event that takes place when certain parameters are met. In BeamNG, every movement has an effect, causing the body and chassis to flex and twist even under normal driving. Currently I would not exactly call it a game that you can play"
date: but more of a "playground" for physics enthusiasts
hoursPlayed: or modders who wish to create their own content.\n\nI would not recommend this game to absolutely everyone
voteText: but I definitely recommend it to anyone who is into simulation and/or modding."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have more hours then stated above since I bought this from the website before it was even considered to be on steam. A rough estimate is around 400 hours.

The game is good if you are in to soft body physics type of games. (like rigs of rods)

PROs:
There is constant updates that add new vehicles, maps, a few bug fixes and stuff like that.
It is a fun game to play if you have a few hours to spare or you just want to play something different for a change.
The community is great for this game, with lots of people making maps[www.beamng.com] and mods[www.beamng.com] for the game. (never download stuff from modsgaming.ru viruses and stuff linger in mods)
The crashing of cars is great and the handling is good.
Game does not crash very often (once in every 6 months or so) unlike some other soft body physics games.

CONs:
You need a good PC to run this. (good cpu, gpu e.t.c)
Sometimes vehicle crashes can be glitchy and will make the vehicle crash (as in freeze type of crash)
The price: Its £18.99 which is a bit much for a game in early acess IMO. Its better then Wreckfest but still a bit much for my liking. I got the game for £10 or so when it had to be bought from the website which is a reasonable price for a game in early acess.
modsgaming.ru thats all I need to say.

Conclusion:
The game is a good game to kill a few hours with and has hours upon hours worth of content when you download mods.
Recommended
8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is absolutely fabulous.

I've played it ever since it came out, about 2 years ago in August. The very first version was completely different to what it is now but it has evolved a heck of a lot since then and it's fantastic to see. The game works fantastically and provides us with a very accurate simulation of vehicular physics, as well as free objects too such as walls, tires, wheels etc.

This game doesn't have an objective, yet. However, if you were to play it, you'd immediately find yourself crashing cars in numerous different ways. Into other cars, through other cars, using the AI, throwing them from a cliff... The list goes on.

The actual game itself is fantastic. It looks good and it feels good. The UI is friendly, simple and professional. It looks great and it works great. It's not something which will leave you feeling confused.

There are lots of levels, open world levels, testing arenas, blank spaces and hilltops plus there is an entire modding community dedicated to making new, exciting terrains for us to use. The terrains look great, they're very well detailed and are huge! You won't be cramped here.

Vehicles are a complete masterpiece. The original vehicles have a ton of detail and look incredible. Every single individual component in every vehicle is distinguished. You can see every strut, spring and shock absorber. When you aim the camera at the bottom of the vehicle, you will see the suspension arms and axles moving accordingly. You can see the leaf springs compressing and bumping against the bump stops. You can see all of this happening, in a game. The vehicles themselves are charismatic and each have their own unique handling characteristics from a small hatchback to a full on, mid-engined supercar. Or, you can drive a dual axle tractor unit. The list honestly is endless, as well as mods too. You won't find yourself short of vehicles to try. Each vehicle is individually customisable down to every last part. Do you want your car to only have a right door and no glass? No problem. Do you want your box truck to have engine tuning and 4WD? No problem. Do you want your pickup truck lowered to the ground and drifting? No problem! You can do it all.

Finally, the game LOOKS incredible. Apparently, emphasis hasn't been put on to the graphics however if this is Beamng not trying, then they must be able!

Don't be put off by the game's early access title. You may run in to some small bugs however their constant updates will make sure your gaming experience is fine. The game can crash, it can give you some painful times but they're not something that happens that often. Not in my experience and not in many other's either.

I highly recommend this game, it's worth every penny.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAs someone who's been doing small track racing in beat-up 4-cylinders since I was 11, I know a few things about damage modeling. I'm very picky with car games, especially ones centered around carnage. Beam.NG, is in my opinion one of (if not the best) soft-body car physics sandbox games out there. The damage portrayed is pretty darn close to the real thing. While it's not perfect it's as close as 2014 technology can really let us experience. Since it's still in Alpha, scratches and rubs don't appear on the side of the cars, but I certainly hope they will when the game is finished. However, while the damage modeling is wonderful, as far as a driving experience, BeamNG.drive doesn't deliver. If you want tight, accurate and realistic car control, look elsewhere. As of (Aug. 14 '14) BeamNG.drive isn't great to drive. The controls are sort of laggy, rear-wheel drive vehicles are near impossible to drive and the standard transmision is rather awkward. That being said, this game is still in developement, and I certainly recomend picking it up. As is, demolition derbies are sort of possible, but just messing around is tons of fun. I certainly enjoy it, and I want this game to become fully polished, so buy it and help it become the perfect driving simulator sandbox thing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The review in pro/con form from somebody who has been here from the beginning.

Pros and Cons in list form; narrative below list:

Pros:
+A driving sandbox.
+Soft-body physics make for amazingly realisitc crashes and deformation.
+Excellent official content
+Very good simulator for any vehicle you can imagine
+Frequent updates (1-2 per month), each with lots of additions (like new vehicles) and fixes
+Vibrant community
+Modding!. Mods like vehicles, aircraft, maps, props etc. created by the community at the game's forums.
+Pretty good visuals (some cons though) Supports up to 4K resolution (to my knowledege)
+Full controller support
+Local multiplayer (like old school Gran Turismo same screen multiplayer)
+In-Game terrain editor.

Cons:
-Sounds (the team is working on this as a current primary objective. I will change this when new sounds are in the game)
-Gameplay aspects lacking. Scenarios are available but are quickly played.
-The lighting visuals seem really weird to me. Headlights are useless at night. I recently saw a quote that said that the headlights are as bright as the sun with a cutoff" proving that there is a lighting issue.
-? The force feedback feels weird; it could be that I don't have it set right but bumps feel rather numb.
+/-Requires a rather good computer to handle (unless you turn off collsion between vehicles)

Narrative
Pros

This is a very good simulator in it's current state. There are not many game aspects to it yet but you have some scenarios given to you such as races or delivery missions. Despite limited concrete gameplay
hoursPlayed: you have total freedom to explore any map you have (official or third-party) in any vehicle you want (official or third-party).\n\nAs of this writing (12/30/15)
voteText: updates are becoming quite rapid fire with loads of new content in each.  From the launch of the game in August
helpfulPercent: 2013 to just about a year ago
votesHelpful: you could tell that the team was struggling; updates took
votesTotal: in the shortest times
votesFunny: 3 to 4 months with mainly "improvements to physics" and little to no content additions. However
commentsCount: for the past six months or so
column16: as the team has expanded with several new
column18: every update has included a new official vehicle
column19: bugs that the community have reported have been hit head-on
column20: and the team's blog and other official information from the team has been clearly given and is more interactive than ever before. I have a feeling that Beta stage is almost here (currently the game is in Alpha)\n\nMoving on
column21: the game comes with a built-in terrain editor. I have experience modding the game via the built-in terrain editor
column22: it is capable and very easy to learn even just by trial and error.\n\nThe community is vibrant and boasts hundreds of mods
column23: be them vehicles such as cars
column29:
and other etc modifications. I highly recommend this game be used with a good steering wheel and pedal setup (my personal bias is towards the Logitech series of wheels).

Cons

Putting the fact that better sounds are being made for the game all around
column31: the sounds are mostly lacking excitement. I concede that they have gotten miles better in recent months to include recently new unique sounds for one of the vehicles and most recently suspension sounds.\n\nAs I said above
column32:
"gameplay" aspects are lacking. There are scenarios but that is it. The team has goals of adding a career mode but it hasn't been said when yet.

This is probably personal but I feel that the force feedback system could be better.

That's all I got :)

Personal notes:

Keep your performance in mind. The game IS VERY CPU heavy
column33: not so much GPU heavy. Keep that in mind. I may go so far as to say that anything older than 5 years old will not play over 30 FPS; anything under 3.0GHz will not play over 30FPS (with collisions on). My 6 year old 2.3GHz gets me 10-15 FPS with collisions on
column34:
~25-35FPS with them off.

Overall:
9.5/10 from me; the updates are very intriguing these days! The game truly gets better with every update."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is absolutely fantastic. I can't think of a single negative thing to say about it- apart from some minor bugs, which are to be expected from a game this early in development. I've watched BeamNG's development since when it was first announced in 2011, and I think it's safe to say that there aren't any games even remotely similar to it. It is truly one-of-a-kind.

BeamNG has hyperrealistic physics, leading to an extremely lifelike driving experience- including crashes. The terrains made for the game are beautiful, scenic, and fun to drive through. The community has made hundreds of different cars and terrains for the game, each of which are unique in their own respect.

One thing I will say: though most of the cars and terrains on the BeamNG Forums are high-quality, some cars (and occasionally terrains) can be found on external websites (known as Russian" mod distributors) that do not utilize BeamNG to the best of its abilities. Often times they are car models ripped from other games and placed on the node/beam structure of an existing developer-made vehicle. As a result
date: the physics and handling are poor and they tend to look strange and unrealistic in crashes. Generally
recommended: use of such mods is frowned upon
hoursPlayed: as they require little effort to produce and they frequently fail to properly credit the original publisher of the mod they are based on. As a general precaution
voteText:
only obtain mods for the game through the official mediums (e.g. the forums or the upcoming repository).

BeamNG is a superb driving sim and I'd recommend it to anyone who likes sandboxes and/or cars in a heartbeat.
"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Poor? Lacking a death wish? Then this game is the game for you! This game is for those people who want to see cars crashed exactly the way they want but can't afford to do that in real life. Basically, this game was made for Americans and terrorists.

On a more serious note, I would like to mention that at the moment, it includes:
A sandbox mode where you can play around in many default maps, and many player-created maps,
A map editor which you can access by pressing F11 while not in full screen mode (Alt+Enter toggles fullscreen),
A Scenario system where you can play scenarios made by both the developers and modders on both stock and user-created maps,
Controller, joystick, and steering wheel support with a very easy-to-use interface for mapping the controls.Remember, this game is still in Early Access and features are being added to it all the time. In the menu, it's obvious that there are plans for a campaign mode. That'll be fun. Don't forget to Subscribe, leave a nice comment, and enjoy some of my other videos!

*Disclaimer: I am not a developer of this game, nor am I aassociated with the developers, I likely missed some important features of the game. For more info, go to the official website for the game at www.beamng.com

reviewText:
Early Access Review

BeamNG is a unique little soft body physics simulation gone car simulator which means it solves a lot of problems with driving looking wrong in other driving games. Things like cars having incredible shock absorbers when landing jumps is not present here. There's no magical forces like in other simulations and cars respond properly to impacts and hard landings. Miles beyond Nextcargame. This is at the cost of CPU performance. You NEED a good CPU for this game. your graphics card doesn't matter so much yet

There are a few things to be aware of; it is an alpha with few features and many bugs present. Currently there's no game as such. Just a way to play with the physics engine. Tire models aren't up to scratch yet so while driving is realistic(ish) all vehicles handle very lazily with a kind of unavoidable floatiness. There isn't a massive quantity of content either. What there is, however, is fun to play with.

If you want a physics sandbox then buy it now. If you want a driving simulator then wait for it to become one. If you want a realistic bridge building simulator... wait for it to become that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Perfect game for any car fan, regardless of age.

There's not a whole lot of fancy graphics, no lens flares, relatively simple smoke/dust effects, most foliage (except trees) are made of flat textures (which are pretty well done, you can't really tell unless you stop and zoom right in on the grass, looks fine if you're driving even at low speeds), and the shaders aren't modified to give a 'cinematic look'. So this game isn't an astonishingly pretty game. But you know what, that's okay.

Each vehicle is intricately modelled, down to the point where you can see each individual part of the engine. You can see the butterfly valves on your supercharged V8 muscle car, you can see the engine block move around in its mounts slightly as you rev the engine. The level of detail is insane. Hit a harsh bump that bottoms out your custom, lowered car? Be prepared to potentially have your entire exhaust system ripped out of your car. Hit a sharp kerb at high speed? Might wanna watch your tires, they can pop, giving your car an unnatural feel. The physical damage in this game is brutally realistic, as each car is not 'hard-coded' with performance stats, health points, etc. Each INDIVIDUAL PART of a car makes up it's whole performance, much like a real car. Pop your front-right tire, and your car will start veering slightly to the right. Fit sport tires, you might be able to handle a corner slightly faster. Lower your suspension, you'll reduce body rolls and keep all 4 tires on the road better, resulting in better grip.
It goes on and on. The soft-body physics overall are brilliant, the cars crumple, wobble, and react exactly how you'd expect a car to react.

Maps:

The maps that come with the game are very nice, and quite varied.
Gridmap: A testing map, with an assortment of jumps, surface types (from sand and dirt to mud and water), slalom cones, objects to crash into and a few high-speed race courses.

Port: A small map set on a port, a perfect map for Gymkhana or drifting fans, with all kinds of shipping containers, warehouses, and a few ramps along with it.

Industrial Site: A medium sized map set on a seaside industrial area, it features a RallyCross track with multiple configurations, an offroad racing track laced with thick mud that will bog down your average rally car, but take a big 4x4 and you'll plow straight on through, and a more traditional tarmac race course. The industrial area also features many warehouses like the Port map, and a nice little circuit that races around it, featuring a jump over a small inlet.

East Coast USA: Set in the East Coast of the USA (As the nae suggests), it has a medium-sized town, along with fairly well maintained roads, that go from the coast to snaking through the forest. Lots of dirt trails through fields and woodlands for rallying around too.

Jungle Rock Island: On a Tropical Island, this map has poorly-maintained roads that call for terrifying high-speed driving along the coastline of this island. It also has many offroad dirt trails that run through the forest, and can quite easily end up getting you lost! There's also a few little rally trails, and industrial areas, quarries, and a port. Probably my favourite map.

Cliff: Spawns you in at the top of a cliff, the only way around is down the cliff. Fun little map for just throwing stuff of cliffs and watching it arrive at the bottom as a mangled mess. Not much to the map other than that, but still fun nonetheless.

Hirochi Raceway: A race-focused map, this raceway is GP-styled, with very wide, smooth corners, along with fast straights and chicanes thrown in. This map also has a few forest routes, that can take you on a narrow road through some forests, so any mistakes can be fatal.
So, quite a few maps, with lots of variety.

Scenarios

The game has a wide variety of scenarios, too many to list here, that cover multiple fun aspects of the game.

These can range from tutorials, to shakedowns of various cars, police chases, races, delivery challenges, even a 'hyper-miling' challenge where you have to cross Jungle Rock Island with very little gas left in your car. There's even a demolition derby scenario for people to 'party play'.


Overall, I'd give this game a 8/10, I'd like to see networked multiplayer (something the BeamNG devs might implement if their engine can support it) and a campaign mode (which the devs have planned pretty much since day 1 of the project)

Lots more potential, the modding community is great, who make new maps, scenarios, vehicles, etc, etc.

Definitely worth the buy, especially for car fans, IMO.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWords can barely describe this game. If you're looking for the next racing game, this isn't it. This is a whole new, and amazing simulator. This game features real time deformation of the cars, with real time simulated car physics. Every crash will be different, every jump will land differently. This game, sorry, simulator, will keep you entertained for hours, if not days. You will constantly find yourself driving into walls, over and over, purely because each time you do, it'll yeild a different result, especially with the option of slowing down time to watch your precious sports car crumple and destroy itself. This simulator is constantly being updated and has a steady flow of work being put into it, the creators constanly update the players as to what their working on and what to expect in future updates. The price it's going for now is a bargain, especially as its supposed to increase in price as time goes on. Did I mention that there is planned to be a multiplayer feature? As if smashing into walls and sliding off roads into trees wasn't fun enough by yourself, you'll be able to destroy your friends' cars as well? Why have you not bought this game(simulator) yet?

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI love realistic games, and this one brings it to a whole new level. This game PERFECTLY simulates real-life physics. There's so many things to do, and you can do anything you want. There's missions, tons of maps, and not to mention a huge selection of modded cars and custom maps. You can even go into the files of a certain car and give it 3000 horsepower if you really wanted to. They are constantly adding new things, and fixing all of the bugs. The customization level is ridiculous. You can drive around with only a frame, wheels, and your engine. Who needs a car body? You can tune your suspension, throw on a supercharger, and much more. I highly recommend this game if you enjoy tinkering with things, or even just driving. NOTE: It will take some getting used to, because the handling is realistic to real life. It's not any old racing game, it takes real skill. Plus you can use a controller. Enjoy ;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

BeamNG.Drive has the weirdest name I've ever heard for a videogame ever.
I can explain part of it, except the NG. You got me there.

For reference, this is a car physics simulation game with some of the most true-to-life physics you can get.

Anyway, back to the name. Beam" refers to how the physics are simulated. The physics part of your car is built out of "beam
date:
these invisible lines that make the physical mesh of your vehicle. They can break, which is where the damage starts to occur. They don't show it in any videos above, but it's definitely a fresh take on physics.

Like I said, NG?"

"Drive
recommended: on the other hand, is self-explanatory.\n\nGive this game a try. I'll be honest, the sound effects are basically worse than gargling broken glass (idk), and the visual look of many of the cars can make you gag (i.e the in-game Volkswagen Golf). If you're like me, you overlook those facts and say OMG THE PHYSICS
hoursPlayed: unless you aren't a complete geek/nerd.\n\nYes, buy this game. It's 25 bucks here, but look on their website! (HINT HINT, they have a humble store link right there that'll save you five bucks and still give you a steam key!)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Brief Review
BeamNG.Drive is a fun sandbox game that simulates every aspect of driving extremely well. You can noticeably feel the difference between heavy cars and light cars, between a stock engine and a souped up one. It's so close to being not just a physic/crashing simulator but if the right mods come out it could potentially become the best Racing sim with many racing genres.

Pros and Cons

Pros

Good modding community
Game leading softbody collisions physics
Surprisingly Good Graphics
Very good Audio (Crashing audio not vehicle sounds)

Cons

Game Updates (Not very often)
Learning Curve

An Ending

When I tried to play it like a videogame, things went predictably poor. It took some time for me to adjust to how the game wanted me to play, but once I did I found there was actually a deeper level of control over what I could make the cars do. Nothing felt unintentional or unexpected about the driving, just very precise with a high learning curve

Cons:

Overall a very good title. If you're short on cash I would wait for a sale or until the game is more complete.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Still Early Access, but this game shows potential!

Having read a bit about the game, and watched the standard YouTube videos about it, I decided to give it a try. Now admittedly I haven't put in a whole lot of hours, because there still are some things that needs to be polished, before a final release is due.

That being said, the game as it is now, is a lot of fun. The physics are unlike any other car game, which really is what sets this game apart right now.
The handling of the cars is very unique, and not two cars feel the same. Depending on the type of car you have chosen, a simple task like driving down the road can become a challenge. I'll bet ya', you'll be wrapping your car around a few trees before you get the hang of the in-game handling.

The game in its current state, already lets you do a bunch of different customization options, and I'm not talking about rims, speakers or the likes here, but stuff like removing parts of the body, removing a wheel, stripping the vehicle down to its core etc.
All things that make the game kind of nerdy, but nerdy in a good way.

The graphics are quite good too, and once you get the hang of controlling your car, you can start venturing into more advanced manuevers like handbrake turns, burnouts and whatever your heart desires.

So for now, in Early Access, the game is for anyone looking to drive around some beautiful scenery, all while tinkering with different setups on your virtual vehicle, and just goofing around basically.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

BeamNG interview between me and myself.

Me: So how do you like BeamNG?

Myself: I love crashing cars!

Me: There are many games where you can smash cars. What makes this game so great?

Myself: Three words. Soft. Body. Physics.

Me: Soft body physics? Can you elaborate?

Myself: Realistic and unlimited vehicle body deformation. More than any game before it. Before BeamNG there was Rigs of Rods. Burnout 3: Takedown has the best vehicular damage in the Burnout series. But that game did not simulate every component of the vehicle. Carmagedon, Dirt, Grid, Flatout and Crashtime all have pretty amazing vehicle physics. BNG is just leaps and bounds ahead of everyone.

Me: Would you recommend the game, even in the early access state?

Myself: Absolutely yes! If your PC can handle it. This is probably the only thing holding the game back. The game is still a work in progress so at times the game runs great, other times not so much. There is a mod community already making vehicles for the game. These can be hit and miss as different versions of the game come out compatiblity changes. So if you find a car that just falls apart you might have to uninstall that mod. The developer content in the game is great so far. Constantly adding new vehicles, maps and scenarios to play. I just love to load up a map and play around with the many vehicle types. It's essentially a physics playground of vehiclular vehicle slaughter.

Me: Wow! that is a lot to take in. Hopefully this answered some questions for the community looking to buy.

Myself: Well if you want you can swing over to my profile page and check out some of the screenshots that I took in game.

Me: Great. I will. Thank you for our time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Who would have thought wrecking a driverless car would be this much fun! Even in its Alpha phase and total lack of objectivity BeamNG.drive is on point, but has plenty of room for improvement. Although the physics are the most realistic and difficult I have experienced, the wrecks and models could use some work. Getting snagged on a tree causes textures to stretch at times. Some parts of the vehicle are static and do not move when you wreck as well.

BeamNG.drive can be best described as a physics engiune diguised as a driving game. Normally, I am greatly against games that have zero objectivity, but in this game's case I can make an exception. I greatly anticipate the improvements as they come rolling in!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a fan of Gran Turismo 4 / 5, BeamNG.drive is very reminiscent of those great racing titles. The soft-body physics are incredible, and the feeling of weight and momentum is amazing. The combination of all these facts means that until they expand the non sandbox modes, all of my time will be spent going 110 down a narrow road and eventually wrapping my car around a tree or flipping it down the road, all in basically photorealistic detail.

Controller DEFINITELY recommended for more precise throttle / steering / braking.

Could really use in the future:
-Multiplayer
-Possibly global competitions / events ala GT5/GT6
-Some sort of music / radio element
-Replay editing

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been testing this game for months now, proud backer of the project.

In its current state it is essentially a massive physics sandbox. I use it mostly to simulate car crashes and pileups, but the possibilities are endless with all the available mods and tracks to work with. Be aware this is NOT a finished product; clearly an alpha, but a fun alpha!

Head on over to the BeamNG.drive forums for the latest content, beta or otherwise. The default cars are nice, but once you pump some custom vehicles and maps into the game it becomes a real treat. The Matrix Freeway and Riverside Expressway maps are my favourite, and there's lots more!

I recommend this game to anyone who wants to mess around with vehicles regardless of the consequences. Better here than in real life, right?

Enjoy the ride!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is the best vehicle simulator/game I have ever played. I have been waiting for this game all my life. I have been following Beamng.Drive since the very beginning and I have always been impressed with what this relatively small development team has managed to create. The game is open-source and mods are easy to make and install. Game play is fantastic, cars handle very nicely, and I love the variation in vehicles and environments. My graphics card is on the slow side (Nvidia GT 620), but I can run this game at fairly good FPS with low settings and lowered resolution for the heavily vegetated maps. There are some occasional problems, but the dev team works quickly to fix any major issues and the game is still in early development. I am excited for what this already amazing game will turn out to be.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I'm going to cut right to the chase.
The Good: An extremely accurate physics engine that does its best to simulate real life as closely as possible.  Official" cars included with the game destroy and deform for the most part as you'd expect they would (you get minor bugs here and there but this doesn't often happen unless you completely mutilate a vehicle).  The official selection of cars is small--a pickup
voteText: a compact coupe
helpfulPercent: a supercar
votesHelpful: a full-size coupe
votesTotal: a full-size van and a semi--but they're all very highly detailed and behave as you'd expect them to behave.  In addition to vehicles
votesFunny: there is a wide variety of other machines and devices you can use to destroy vehicles (including a roller crusher
commentsCount: a centrifuge and a car cannon).  The environments provided are again few
column16: but nicely varied and include sections of countryside
column19: industrial areas and more.  The really big pro here?  The game is totally open to the modding community.  There are lots of cars
column20: props and maps available to drive
column21: and they run the gamut from plain family cars to rally specials and science-fiction wonders. The modded terrains range from rally stages to highways to elaborate obstacle courses to who knows what else.  The official terrains are very well designed and pretty
column22: if a bit lifeless.  They're also quite large and have a lot of little secrets hidden all throughout them--secrets that can often only be accessed by a particular type of vehicle.\n\nThe Bad: Despite being in production for well over a year
column23: the game is still in a very early state.  There are lots of features still missing (there is no multiplayer
column24: AI is primitive at best).  And then there's the other problem--this game is a MASSIVE resource hog.  All the physics calculations are done in real time.  There are ZERO canned crash animations
column25: unlike a game like GTAV.  GTA uses canned animations to save on CPU overhead and preserve framerate.  Beamng.drive does not.  Because of that you are going to need a very good PC to run this game on high graphics settings and keep a reasonable framerate.  Also
column26: because of the early state of this game there...really isn't all that much to DO.  There are a few "scenarios"
column28: but other than these there's no real point besides driving around and figuring out new and inventive ways to destroy a late 90s pedo-van.  Also
column29: this is a car-based driving game with car-based controls.  There are working boats and aircraft in the modding community but the control scheme is not designed to accomodate them.  Because of that they can be very hard to handle.  Another point against--the game works decently well with a gamepad
column30: but to take full advantage of it you are going to need a decent steering wheel and pedal setup.  DO NOT attempt to play this game with just a keyboard and mouse.\n\nSo should you buy this game now?  Well that depends.  Are you the kind of gamer that enjoys driving games?  Can you make your own fun?  Do you like to break stuff?  I'd say if you answered yes to at least two of those three questions
column31: you should give this game a good hard look.  If however you're the kind of gamer that needs direction
column32: needs to be given something to do
column33: this game probably isn't for you."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

First off, I absolutely love this game. It's amazingly fun to just mess around with, and try to make really interesting crashed happen. This is definitely the most realistic car physics simulator out there, but keep in mind, that's about all it is. The developers have added some fun little missions to do, but they aren't really that good and you don't get any reward or even acknowledgement for beating them, they're sort of just there so the game isn't a complete sandbox. That being said, there is much more in the works, such as multiplayer, racing, and many other fun things that I cannot wait for. This also is a pretty big game, I'd recommend having a good computer to get the game's full effect. (My $200 Toshiba isn't exactly doing it for me) There are truly some amazing mods, including actual makes and models (ex. Ford Crown Vic, Ferrari F50, etc.) and even rocket cars and planes. They are up there with the stock cars the developers put out, work just as fine, and in my experience, have no extra bugs or glitches. (Though I do have to point out, you would do completely fine without mods because the developers did an truly amazing job putting out a variety of different vehicles, including semis, trucks, drift cars, your everyday sedans, police cars, hyper cars, vans, off-road variants of trucks, and sports cars. Keep in mind though that all of these cars are by fake car companies, so if you are looking for realism, download mods.)

The other cool thing about BeamNG is that it is super-customizable. You can change the cars, (ex. remove/change parts or switch engines) change the time of day, mess around with the gravity, use slow motion ,(Highly recommened, crashes look awesome in slow motion with the amount of detail in this game) and even add in AI's to chase you around or crash into. This is another fun aspect of this game that I love, and I use the features mentioned above a lot.

Minor problems I have with the game:

-Engine sounds. Most of the engine sounds that are in the stock cars the game comes with are the same, which can be sort of disappointing to a car guy. You do get some different sounds with modded cars, but you still get mainly one droning engine sound, which doesn't really sound good either.

-Water. In most cars, even the modded ones, going into water that is a little bit bigger than a big puddle on a real road kills the engine. This is really getting nit-picky, but when I try off-roading in a car that wasn't specifically built for it, even on just a bit of water, the engine dies.

-Crash sounds. Almost every single sound of vehicles impacting something is met with the same exact sound. It is a realistic sound, but it gets annoying after a while hearing the same sound over and over when you crash it.

-Lack of actual gameplay. I did already address this, but once again, if you are looking for something other than a sandbox, wait for the game to finish Early Access or go somewhere else, because as of now, this is almost 100% a sandbox.

Although there are a few things missing right now, I would definitely recommend this game to anyone with even a slightly better computer than mine and who just wants to mess around with cars and physics for a while. I have so far played this game for 80+ hours (Keep in mind I usually get around 15fps with my computer having -15 gb of ram) and I still have fun every time I open BeamNG. Updates are frequent and usually big, with either bugs fixed or new cars being added just about every time. Definitely buy this game if you want a sandbox, but you should wait a while if looking for real gameplay. Rating: 9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Physics 10/10
Handling 9/10
Content 6/10

This game is great. I have been there almost since the beginning, and the progress that has been made in regards to physics, handling, and optimization are truly significant. This is more sim like than the arcade style games you may be accustomed to, as cars feel like they actually have weight and proper driving characteristics. It is near impossible to play properly with a keyboard and mouse, I would highly recommend at least a game pad if not a wheel.

The realistic handling and crashphysics are superb, the fact that there is less content than I would like does not change the fact that this game is sick! (and i am sure content is coming in future updates)

Buy it

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Racing games are not our cup of tea, but after not playing these types of games for years we felt t was time to try playing them again.
First this is not just about racing, it is also a vehicle simulator that shows the results of crashes if intentional.. There are challenges, competitions, multiple courses, a track editor, multiple style cars and engines to choose from and the ability to modify the vehicle.
Second this is still a game in development.
Third it is not a threat to any of the GTA games. They have their own draw.
Fourth This game may operate much smoother with a steering wheel pedal combo.
Lastly is the cost, although it is above the $20 mark, if you like racing sims you will want to add this to your collection.

So everybody get your game on and get behind this steering wheel for a cruise.

It's definitely worth the money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Whilst I would recommend this game, there a few points I want to show.

1) As a non-expert on cars it can be difficult when it comes to tuning when you have about 15 different sliders/values to change. It would be nice to have a few pre-sets I often found steering was difficult in a few cars (and I didn't understand what values/sliders to change to perhaps make it better)

2) This is a really fun 'sandbox' but to me it's not quite a game, if you want to spend your hours crashing cars a lot or zooming around then I'd say go for it. There's a local multi-player mode but if you're like me and you don't have friends in real life that will play with you then ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

3) The price is expensive in comparison to what you're getting, just a suggestion but I would say about £10-£12 for this game max and you'd probably find you'd get a lot more sales.

I'll come back to this game in the future and just have another looksie and see if these points mentioned have been addressed in a way. Overall this game is very advanced and the physics are really well done and when you crash the damage feels so realistic.

9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TL;DR summary:
Overall BeamNG.drive is one of the best soft body car shenanigans simulator out there, and it's completely worth its price. I bought the alpha early on, about a year ago, and I'm still having fun with it now. If you like the physicsy simulationy type of sandbox game you'll definitely be impressed with BeamNG.drive and end up messing around with it for a long time (and that's not including the wide variety of mods available)!

There's a racing mode and other new features coming out soon, and I hope they turn out as well as everything else.

Regarding Next Car Game, NCG is more of a desruction derby focusing on wide areas and chunks of destruction with a ton of broken pieces flying around; it's more of an action-orientated game. BeamNG.drive is a realistic physics simulator sandbox. NCG and BeamNG.drive are both good at doing what they are designed to do, but in my view they're pretty different.

TL;DR reviewy thing:
Crash Physics: The physics are extremely realistic and efficient with minimal glitching; every crash inflicts different and varying amounts of damage upon each vehicle.
Car Detail: The cars are detailed in terms of aesthetics (the detail of the exterior and interior of the vehicles) and mechanics (wheel torque, suspension, chassis integrity) with results extremely similar to their real-world counterparts.
Graphics and Sound: The graphics are decent with no visual effect bugging as of now. The sound works for what it is but isn't made all that well; a sound overhaul is planned.
Mods: The mods are plenty and great, very high quality. You can pilot airplanes and do the coolest trix.
Controls: There are many controls and it is sometimes hard to press all the buttons needed to control vehicles. Vehicles can sometimes feel sticky or slippery.


For those who are willing to take upon themselves the challenge of reading a huge block of text:

Summary:
BeamNG.drive is one of the most realistic car physics/damage simulators up to date. Utilizing a real-time soft-body physics engine powered by Torque3D, it successfully emulates breakable and malleable surfaces applied to cars. The physics demonstration that BeamNG.drive is capable of is nearly identical to real-world movement; footage of in-game crashes have been compared to real-world test crashes with minimal differences.

Reviewy thing:
Crash Physics: It's amazing how the physics are simulated, with every surface on every car bending and breaking differently in every situation (surfaces are warped in accordance to the surfaces they come in contact with resulting in unique damage, rather than calling up a stored damage model" when a car hits something a la GTA car physics or the such). This is where the "Beam" of BeamNG.drive comes in. I'm not that knowledgeable about the details of the physics simulating but it can be thought of like a detailed
date: intricate grid on a surface with each point moving when it hits something. I have not encountered many bugs in the physics so far
recommended: but if pushed far beyond real-world limits the physics do cause model glitches. Sometimes meshes and textures will crumple and stretch weirdly after paricularly intensive crashes. For what it is
voteText: it works wonderfully and efficiently

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Good stuff about the game below. Will update this as more updates come.

Right now I'm guessing it's maybe 1% finished. The only content in the game are maps and cars (of which 99% is made by community). But the core is there. Also there are a couple of missions and races to try after the last big update.

There are some amazing vehicle mods out there. And there are a lot of fun maps, too. Most people MIGHT get bored from the current state of the game though because there is almost nothing to do: You just load a map, choose a car, and crash it as you please. Or don't. You can drive around if you want. That's it. Oh you can add a stupid AI to follow you or run from you but that's about it. You can also add multiple AIs. They are also working on AI improvements as well.

Now on to the good stuff:
+ I cannot emphasize enough how good the crashing mechanic is (flagship feature). It's ♥♥♥♥ing amazing. The game's name derives from the fact that they are using the Beam technology on car design (I think it's their own engine). The cars are created out of beams. That's why crashes are so realistic and fun. Every beam gets deformed on its own, according to the applied force, the angle of the force, the momentum and ♥♥♥♥.
+ Beautiful graphics. To my taste, this is cutting edge
+ You can even mod your own engine sound
+ Mod maps and cars, or download the ready ones
+ Day/night concept is there (editable)
+ Destruct your car in a variety of ways
+ Multiple cameras (duh)
+ Slow motion at your disposal
+ You're in for a lot of laughs
+ Or join the modding forums on the website and be surprised to find out that someone designed your dream car into the game. Now download and crush it.
+ Career is coming at full release
+ ♥♥♥♥in' A

**The only con I can think of is the required system to play the game at it's full capacity. I'm sure they will optimize it further but right now as it is, the game needs a powerful computer to run. Especially when you spawn multiple cars to crash or enter a foresty area. When crashing multiple cars together, it might lag a lot on average computers.**

It has a vast potential, and the devs are aiming for a free-roam, career thingy, in which you will be able to buy junk cars and reform them into racing machines or pretty eye candies, you will be able to complete jobs, missions, races, deliveries, derbies, free-roam, all of that.

But that would be a long way off from now. They say the game will be in this phase for about a year from now. So buy at your own risk (not that it's a risk actually, there is just not any content right now).

When this game gets finished, it might be the very first 'driving' game that I have given 10/10 my whole life. Because currently there isn't any open world 'driving' game with realistic driving concept which also includes careers and mods. There just isn't any. Any potential rival games that come close to this, either ruin it by sucking at graphics or by making it online, or by making it a linear racing game (don't even get me started on NFS series).

So I recommend it for people who like to smash cars with the best possible physics available, and who like community made cars and maps, and a realistic driving.

There is also wheel support with manual gears.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

By far, my favorite Racing/Driving game at the moment. Amazing damage physics (as real as you will find), a promising future for the game play and content (Including an actual Semi to crush other vehicles with), and, of course, the open slate for modifications and level editors. I will admit, the controls are twitchy and keeping control is hard in this current state, but regardless, this game is a must have for any Automotive Enthusiast, no matter your involvement. The current customization may not be diverse, but it shows just how far they will take us into what you want your car to be. Truly, this is Automotive Heaven, it just isn't finished yet. Try the tech demo and feel for yourself:
http://www.beamng.com/content/
Or watch someone have fun with the amazing physics:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yiCp0w2D53I
For the record, No. Obviously this is not me playing BeamNG. It is a known Youtuber. Even so, it displays what the game is about very well, and if watching an Irishman wreck cars in the most realiztic way possible doesn't sell this game to you, i don't think anything will.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is not a game in the traditional sense.

It is however the most satisfying damage physics I've ever controlled in a peice of playable software.

The 'scenarios' allow you to challenge yourself to various checkpoint based time trials against the clock. But this is only a sideline compared to free-roaming the maps in various iterations of a modest but broad selection of very well modelled vehicles.

If the future GTAs, Project Cars or similar can wrangle this kind of powerful physics then the future is bright for ultra-realistic, satisfying vehicular gameplay.

You shouldn't be turned off by the Early Access nature of the game. The level which the game is at currently IS worth £19 in my opinion. However this might seem steep to anyone who prefers a story-lead game with a much more led set of scenarios.



8/10 - If the updates stay regular, WELL worth it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nIn BeamNG.drive you can almost destroy your car/vehicle any way you want from crashing it into something as fast as you can or taking a truck to go obliterate it.  It's only single player right now and hopefully multiplayer will be added around final release.  The physics can get a bit wonky and things will fall off your vehicle from no stress at all nearly. When you get stuck inside something, there is a reset button for your vehicle and it's great but if your stuck between a prop and a wall, it sometimes won't work. If you like realistic cars this game is for you, but you need a good computer to run it.  it's early access so things are supposed to happen that will be fixed like bushes acting as invincible blocks that can destroy your vehicle to shreds and invincible trees acting as spider web when you drive into them too fast.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Everytime I play this game, its a new experience. I bought BeamNG over a year ago and I'm still playing it, I may only have 38.8 hours on steam, but I have 100+ when I bought the alpha on the website :)

+Constant Updates

+One Of The Best Looking Games Ever

+TONS OF MODS

+SLOW MOTION
+Senarios!
+Early Steering Wheel Support

-Some Patches Make Game Laggy
-Some Times UI Is Broken
-Impact Lag is Common
-Can Get Boring After A While, Play This Game In Bursts, Not Long Sessions.

Please keep in mind that this is a Early Access game, some of the problems can be fixed and there is more to be added every week :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't usually write reviews... ever actually. But I feel this game can't go without one. I've been playing this game since September of 2013 and it simply never gets old. There is a lot of talk about there not being much gameplay yet, which is partially true. It doesn't have a story mode or a campaign, (Not yet at least) but to be honest it doesn't need to. The normal sandbox mode is endless entertainment, and with the new addition of 'Scenarios', (Time trials and timed challenges) there is more playable content than ever. The scenarios are actually quite difficult and it will surely take many hours to complete them all. And on top of that, you can share your times with members on the forum to be put on a leaderboard. Aside from the scenarios though, it's really a game meant for imagination and experimentation. Just thinking of every way possible to wreck any car I want leaves endless possibilities. As a kid who grew up on racing games, I've always dreamed of a game where every action you have has an equal reaction. One where you actually have to drive carefully in order to succeed. And that's exactly what BeamNG is. You can spend endless hours on this game whether you're crashing cars, flying planes, (And even sailing ships, soon) offroading, stunting, and even content creating with the excellent mod support this game has. It may get boring after an hour or two of just driving around and exploring, but for some reason I always keep coming back to it. I'll admit, it's not for everyone. It requires patience, imagination, and a curious mind. But honestly, if you've ever been interested in doing outrageous things with vehicles that you could never do in real life, than this is the game you need to get. It offers a ridiculous number of possibilities with real-life outcomes. It's truly the most realistic driving game I've ever played.

Pros:Insanely beautiful graphics.
Lifelike soft-body physics.
Enough maps, cars, and objects to keep you entertained for days.
Multiple 'Scenarios' where you can test your time and driving skill.
Very advanced settings so you can set EVERYTHING perfectly.
Customizable UI with multiple interesting apps.
Camera mode for easy, beautiful screenshots.
Extremely realistic vehicles. The models/textures are nearly exact in every aspect.
Working dashboards, gas tanks, lights, and trailers.
Real-life aerodynamics, time, gravity, and physics.
Crazy props to destroy your cars with.
Realistic maps that can take hours to explore.
Time trials on supported maps
Amazing forum community.
Easy mod support from the talented modders on the forum.*
Mods such as planes, boats, offroaders, machines, maps, skins, apps, and more.
Relatively easy to mod yourself, if you have the time to learn.
Chat room and repository (Soon)
TRULY regular updates. It's a small team but they really stepped up.
Cons:Takes a decent computer to run well.
Probably boring if you aren't a little creative.
Crashes often (But what can you expect when you slam a car into a wall at 300mph in a virtual physics engine that's early access?)
I don't personally use a racing wheel, but I hear the game has little support for them. I'd look into that more if this applies to you.
TL;DR
If you've ever wanted to see or do anything crazy with a vehicle that you can't do in real life, buy this game. It's one of the most good-looking games I've ever seen, and it's the most realistic physics simulator I've ever seen. If you are at all interested in it, just get it.

*I'd like to make this very clear that I said on the forum". Never download a mod that wasn't originally posted to the official BeamNG forum. Around the BeamNG community
date: a few Russian websites have become very well known for publishing false mods. They are simple vehicle models ripped off from somewhere on the internet and then slapped onto the jbeam (The code and skeleton that makes vehicles in this game crash and function) of an existing default vehicle. This results in
hoursPlayed: a car that looks like a Lamborghini but handles and crashes like a Crown Vic. These mods could have viruses in them
voteText: and without a doubt will not function well. If you do insist to download these however
helpfulPercent: I believe I speak for the community when I say to not publish videos or pictures of them. Like I said
votesHelpful: they don't function the way they're meant to and in short
votesTotal: just make the game look bad. I just thought I'd give a fair warning."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Been playing this from time to time, and the brutally unforgiving physics and ridiculous playground design have been nothing short of amazing, like some of the best memories of San Francisco Rush and QWOP packed into the same experience, though with a with a much looser structure.  The scenarios are often checkpoint based, but there's usually no time limits, so you can just drive around or reset the car, or even change the car, weather, etc. whenever you feel like it.  It often feels like a test to see how far you can push your own ability (and the car itself) since one accident and you generally render the car undriveable.

As a heads up, this game is very demanding on hardware and doesn't run very well on my 4-5 year old PC, even with the setting turned low.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My BeamNG.drive experience:
https://youtu.be/ClhpN_Feud8
Not the best quality but it gives you an idea.

BeamNG.drive really is a nice game. I personally adore sandboxes, just because you can do whatever you want. The fact that you can download mods makes it even better, you are actually encouraged to install mods and expand the possibilities to the max. I don't have a drivers license, so I can't say much about how the verhicles handle in comparison with real ones, however, I know enough about physics to say that it is pretty damn good. For example, when you brake slowly without slipping instead of completely burning your tires, you will actually brake faster because the braking force is higher. When you accelerate when your vehicle is flying through the air, you won't see your actual speed because your tires don't touch the ground. Next to all those details you can also place small apps on the screen that show engine info, like the force from the engine itself, the force from the tires, windspeed, weight, G-force, etc. etc. The game does contain some minor bugs, but because it is still an early access game, I don't mind.

Overall: 7,5/10
