reviewText:
Early Access Review

As it stands, BeamNG is an incredibly fun vehicle-crashing sandbox with amazing soft body physics. Promises of career modes and other such things aside, BeamNG already contains a decently sized selection of meticulously detailed maps and vehicles--and even more are available to download thanks to the modding community.

As of writing this though, this IS still very much an alpha. I haven't experienced any instability but the sounds are still placeholders and some things like the UI and the tyre physics could use some polishing. Still, I personally find it very enjoyable in its current state.

If you enjoy destruction-based sandboxes such as Red Faction, or are frustrated with the pathetic vehicle damage models from driving games these days, then this is for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The first day I played, I selected a random map, I started to drive using the controller and 5 seconds later my car was broken. :C The next day I played, I rammed a small cube and my engine stopped working. The day after that, I set the gravity to negative earth and I was FLYING!!!! and then my friend sitting next to me set the gravity to sun and I had to restart the game. :C The day after, I raged because there was a mini ramp and I went up the ramp and I flipped the car onto it's roof and I stopped playing for 3 days. After the 3 days I finally came back and I got flipped again.

I rate it 9.9/10
It has very good graphics.
It has really fluid animation.
The physics are just brilliant.
Overall, it is a really good game. I recommend it for people who love to smash up cars and like to be smashed in first person view.

Early Access Review

If the devs read this, please make the clutch necesary when in manual.


After 70 or so hours I figure I should write a review on this game.
First off I would like to correct the store page, when it says local co op it's a competitive demolition derby, it's is a very different style of gameplay to the regular driving, it's unique and very fun in it's own way, however it does require at least one other person to be there with you. Soooo I personally don't like reading the big long in depth reviews so I am just gonna put some pros and cons say a few final words and be done.
Pros:
-Good graphics
-Pretty good sound fx
-delicious phisics
-Lots of fun scenarios (more added frequently and community made scenarios)
-Lots of player made content
-Level editor/creator (never used it myself but it's cool that it's there)

Cons:
-You dont need to use the clutch to shift even when in a fully manual" driving mode.
-Nearly unplayable on a keyboard (wheel is best
date: but I put a good 30 of my hours on a gamepad)\n-Not very well optimised (on a normal $450 computer on min graphics I got around 30-40 fps
recommended: now I have a great gaming rig and I get a solid 60 fps unless I turn on dynamic reflictions
hoursPlayed:
then I get 40-55 fps)
-Takes a little while to set up a wheel for it
-When you get driving it steals hours (I once drove for 4-5 hours straight in the same car on the same map)

Bottom line

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game exists solely to show off the soft body physics of the cars.  That being said, it does it in spectacular form.  Its absolutely hilarious.  At this point, the game is in alpha, which they make very clear going in, so as it is at the time of this writing, there's not a lot of content.  I've also come across a couple of bugs, but its pretty stable as a whole.  There are several maps that are fully explorable, a handful of vehicles with different variations, and some scenarios to play with are available, but it's best to try and make your own fun.  The game supports mods as well, but I haven't been able to get any to work yet.  Its thoroughly entertaining overall, so I am excited to see what else gets added to the game.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is definitely one of the best racing games I've ever played.  Its fun, realistic, and creative, thanks to the dedicated mod community and wonderful devs who keep us updated on their website beamng.com/blogs/ with a weekly summary of their work.  I've put at least 20 hours into the game before it came on Steam, and I have no intention of stopping.  This game already has no ceiling to how amazing it can be, and there isn't even any sort of structure to the gameplay.  Its a simple load map, load vehicle, drive to your heart's content affair that is both incredibly relaxing and engagig.  I love making rally courses to run through without wrecking and just running through them over and over.  There is no time limit, no opponents, and no objectives.  Only you, the car, and the road.  The great bit is that each game is a new adventure because there aren't any rules as to where you can and can't go, leaving it up to you to decide how to explore and play with the environment you're given.  And then there is the main selling point of this game: the crash physics.  How the devs did it, I have no idea.  Watching your car get bent in half around a tree after a botched high-speed turn is a sight like no other.  For those of us hell-bent on obliderating our cars, there is a map called Insane Testing" by Insanegaz on the mod forums featuring spikes

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At first I saw this game as a fun crash simulator. As I played more, I became fascinated at how realistic the driving physics are, despite employing a completely different paradigm to anything else. In the past, i've found physics based titles (not just car games) to have a plethora of silly physics glitches, making them difficult to play or impossible to take seriously. I bought a Thrustmaster T300RS Racing wheel recently, and despite having a dozen other car games in my collection, I find myself coming back to this one. It really shines with a wheel, and you'll find that the force feedback is a unique experience compared to anything else. Oh and the crashes are spectacular of course.

Recommended.

PROS
+ Surprisingly nice graphics, looks almost raytraced at times
+ Novel approach to vehicle handling that that is fun but realistic
+ Industry-leading softbody physics
+ Good controller support, with support for shifters and clutch pedals. I'm even using an old joystick as a handbrake.
+ Force feedback for wheels is great when tuned
+ Mod support; more vehicles, more maps, more fun

CONS
- Poor performance on a 980 Ti a good bit of the time. 45-50 FPS in a lot of maps.
- Needs some tweaking to get ingame steering wheels to turn 1:1 with your wheel controller
- No multiplayer... yet

NEUTRAL
- VR support better be on the roadmap
- Steam Workshop would be better than the current mod install system

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of 6/17/2015: EARLY ACCESS.
In it's current state, it's more of a car accident simulator than an actual game, though there are a few pre-cursors to a career mode - a few challenges and such.   This aside, let's get on to the real deal here.
An absolutely hands-down realistic soft-body driving simulator, most likely more realistic than what you see in drivers training computer systems.  Not only can you shift gears (multiple transmission modes, arcade automatic, real auto, manual, manual with clutch), you can use signals, hazard lights, headlights/highbeams, and the signal stalks and shifter moves as you shift it - gauges work too and if you clobber the car so badly the check-engine light comes on!.  It's extremely well thought-out, and if you ever have played Rig-of-Rods, it's all the fun that was, and way way more fun.

Welcome to the Garry's Mod" of CARS.  I can't really explain it better than that.  When you fly too fast through a corner
hoursPlayed: your car becomes a crumpled undriveable mess of mangled steel.  This isn't GTA

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's not really a driving game, it's more of a car simulator. Like Spintires, but with a heavy focus on soft body destruction. The video below shows some real life car crashes recreated in beam.ng and it should really drive home what an impressive piece of software this is. Its fun to try things that would get you killed in real life and watch how a car would respond, but it;s also fun just tooling around in really accurately physics modeled cars and watch your pick up truck stall out on a steep incline, or shift gears too quick and throw a rod, or whatever. Also there are tons of things to download on the forums where there is a huge community of moders. It's not a racing game or whatever but it's a very cool thing and if you are on the fence I would certainly recommend it.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jCbz4gqJgYg

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review is based on the alpha version of the game, up to the date August 11th, 2014.

If you like realism, destruction, and cars, this is the game for you.

I'd like to begin by discussing what exactly Drive is. Drive is a state-of-the-art physics simulator that runs Torque 3D as the main physics engine. In this environment, every movement and input is calculted and recalculted over and over again as the game moves. So, as you come around a corner with your tail out, the computer is taking your car's weight, road surface, throttle, brake, gas, size of the contact patch of the tires, and many more variables into account every second. This allows the game to make an accurate representation of what is going on. Continuing with my example, if you nicked a bump in the road, millions more calcultions would take place, throwing the car around and whatnot. Another important feature that is simulated is air, which, for the time being, is being experimented with.

So

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI think this game is amazing, being still in a alpha it has enough in the game already to make it fun not to mention it has a awesome modding community. But the as is game does have its problems. Such as car engine sounds (its the same sound for all the cars). And no controller support right out of the box so to speak. There is ways to get the controller support but its though a third party and its difficult to get it working. But the one major problem is the handling. Its almost impossible to keep the cars going in a straight line with a keyboard and mouse. its easier if you have a racing wheel like a G27 but not everyone does. Hopefully in the future they will sort all this out as the game goes into beta. I think there is a great future ahead for this game as long as the devs don't give up.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBeamNG Drive Early Access. I bought this game a while back and I finally got a Steam key. So here is my review. BeamNG Drive is a driving simulator but not really. I think it is more of a vehicle crash simulator. The crash physics are great and the driving physics are getting there. I really like it. The biggest thing that bugs me is the computer performance. Now, I may not have a gaming PC but I can play other games on medium-high graphics and have no trouble. But on this game, it struggles. A little problem is clipping and fall-through. Clipping is when I crash into another vehicle and the textures clip into each other. Therefore wedging the cars together. Fall-through is my term when a car falls through another car. For example, loading the hatchback into the box truck (of course I remove the doors). I drive the car in and it falls out the bottom of the truck. The bad parts are little enough where the good parts stand out. Overall, a great game. I recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There's a lot to BeamNG Drive. It's probably best known because of the amazing, unique, real-time physics make the cars deform very realistically.
Most games that have a decent damage system only seem to deform very well somewhere past the more gentle bumps and bashes, but somewhere before the really extreme, high-speed crashes, that would turn a car into mangled pulp, which does take quite a lot of joy out of that insane crash-stunt-thing that you managed to pull off.

BeamNG, though, as the damage is calculated while you are crashing, will have the cars deforming well no matter what end of the scale you push it to- you can watch the very slight deformation that comes from driving a car slightly too hard, and see the little dents and and bashes, all the way up to the car being crushed to such an extreme that the car is left only a couple of inches tall- a phenomenon that is usually caused by setting the gravity to a level that makes the cars float off the ground, before suddenly changing the gravity levels to that of the sun itself.

But, although that is all amazing, and can bring a LOT of fun, and be interesting to observe, it is not the focus of the game, and it is, for me, not the best part of the game.

At the time of this review, there are three environments that I consider particularly noteworthy, and a few smaller environments.
All of the maps are extremely detailed, and contain a lot to explore. They don't even prevent you from leaving the roads!
Sure, there isn't a huge amount to find away from the beaten path, but if you're like me, then you've probably had that moment in a racing game, when you've just stopped and looked at how beautiful the landscape is, and had a strong desire to go drive all over it.

BeamNG won't surprise you with anything super-amazing if you try to do that, but it won't disappoint, either.
That hill will be there, and you'll be able to actually drive all over it, and it will be almost exactly what it looked like it was- although, I will note that it will, in one or two maps, while still turning out to be what it looked like, Also reveal that at the bottom of the other side of the hill, the map suddenly ends in a void.
It isn't a huge thing, but it would be a bit more immersive if they'd thrown a random ocean there, or something.

Then, of course, most importantly, there is how the cars feel when you drive them. This is probably the main point of the game, and the most important aspect of any racing game.
Now, they handle very realistically-there are a few issues to iron out still, but heck, it's an early alpha game and they've already got it THIS realistic? It's pretty insane.
But, I'm going to focus on how it feels to drive them. This is the most important point for most gamers, if they are not hardcore simulator fans.

A lot of people have been complaining that the cars are too hard to control, but I'm just using a Logitech F710 -that is, a gamepad with the layout of a PlayStation controller, that emulates a 360 controller, minus the deadzone- and it isn't TOO hard to control the cars.
They’re a little hard to control if you’re trying to push them to their limits, but they’re not too hard, and you can always just drive them gently, which is plenty easy.
In fact, I don't understand why this game is getting flack for how hard it is to control the cars, when games like Assetto Corsa seem to have few complaints, yet, when I'm playing Assetto I often find that one minute the car feels like it's very stable, and despite the fact that I'm starting to slide it, it feels like I have a LOT of control- then, suddenly, because I applied slightly too much throttle, I find myself backwards and in a cloud of tyre smoke, without any warning, wondering what just happened.
BeamNG, though, feels so...Natural. Nothing feels forced. If I push too hard, I can see very clearly that the car is slipping out of my control, which sometimes gives me enough of a chance to catch it before it spins- or, at the very least, to put the game in slow motion so that I can watch as the dents form in the car.

Y'know, I've always had a thing about watching cars leaning and/or bouncing on their suspension. I can’t really describe it.
This game succeeds in giving me the same kind of feeling I get from watching a car's suspension smoothly dealing with a sudden change in elevation, or dealing with the weight shifting to the front of the car under heavy breaking, in real life; I don't remember ever getting that feeling from another game.

And, of course, I could talk for days about how detailed, and beautifully designed the cars in this game are.
They are very similar to cars that are in reality, yet they are not blatant ripoffs; they have their own look, and their own charm...
Rather like real cars do.
They are FAR more detailed than the models in most games, and if you pay attention, you'll notice that the interior of the car is actually part of the model, and you can see it in all it's glory from 3rd person view, if you manage to get the camera to be looking in the window.

...I'll stop here, before this gets any longer. Even as it is, it'll be a pain in the neck to proofread.

I will note, though, that the game is very resource intensive. back when I got the game (the day after it was first released), I only had an old-ish laptop, and, as I expected, it got an average of about 20 FPS with the least CPU intensive cars, which was not very playable. But, I now have an AMD FX-8320, which is OC'd to 4.4 GHz, and a Sapphire 7870 HD, and it runs the game as smoothly as a Codemaster game's menu animation.
You should make sure that your computer has enough power before you buy the game, or you may be somewhat disappointed. And, don't expect to be able to run a tonload of cars, either.
If you have a good CPU, you'll be able to run about 6 cars at once.

Also, don't expect a complete, polished game, because it isn't. It's an early alpha release, being worked on by a VERY small team, and this game is more advanced than any driving game before. EVER. So don't expect it to be developed at lightning speed. The devs are releasing updates at a good pace, but the bigger changes and features can take a few months to implement, and there are a few [small issues] to deal with at the moment, such as slightly tacky engine sounds.

TL;DR: Amazing physics, good graphics, good maps, good devs, good game. Shut up and take my money. And the money of whoever is reading this review, for that matter.

I expect I'll come back in the future and update this review as the game progresses.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game, it's finally gotten to steam! So happy :3 Now to the review, this game is really good, but lacks some polishing. Of course, it's still on early alpha, yada yada, but it could be better. The video quality is great, but has some framelag every now and then, and some audio failures when you break. The controls are a bit confusing too, but they are good, for people who use a controller, not if you use a keyboard, because if you do, sorry.
Bad things aside, this game is incredibly enjoyable, and with mods it gets even better. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys racing games, simulation games and physics games. I love this game a lot and see a lot of potential in its future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have played this game coutless hours since alpha was released in 2013.

This game had mod support from day 1. If you know your way around a 3D Program and learn how to implement your models into the in game engine, you can make pretty much anything you want.
Some of the most innovative vehicles for this game came from the community, which is a cool thing in my opinion.

The game is still in development and the potential of it is almost unfathomable. I expect more great things to come from the devs and the community.

There is something relaxing about smashing cars into walls... but this game is about more than just crashing. I truly enjoy just driving around and with the race update coming soon (I hope multiplayer eventually) There is no doubt that this game will be huge.

10/10 Best vehicle physics on the market.

Next Car Game: go suck a donger.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Right now BeamNG has a great physics engine going for it, but not much else. Slow motion crashing is surprisingly entertaining though, and I've sunk a good few hours just smashing stuff up.

However, a lot of potential is taken away by the extremely dodgy car and camera controls. Camera in the game tends to drift in the exact opposite direction you want it to go, forcing you to constantly hold down the right mouse button to control it. Cars don't seem to have any grip on road surfaces and slide around uncontrollably if you choose to drive faster than a granny on her way to shop groceries. In short, the cars don't drive well and you will fly off the road if you go faster than 40mph....which DOES look very nice, but you'll have to weight that against there being literally nothing else in the game that works, as of now.

It's still early in development, so only buy it now if you really enjoy soft body physics, otherwise wait for more features and improvements on the existing ones.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI am very picky when it comes to driving/racing games. I like the feel of the cars to be realistic, which is exactly what BeamNG.drive gives me. The cars not only drive well, but the default terrains look spectacular, and the modding community is rapidly growing. None of this, however, compares to the stunning physics this game provides. BeamNG.drive allows me to see what would happen if I crashed a 1980s sports car into a tree, but without having to injure myself in the process. Overall, even though it is only in Alpha, this is the most polished sandbox driving simulators I have ever used.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's strangely tharaputic.  Going between trying to do the set up tracks, crashing into walls, flipping your car violently, and calmly driving down a dirt road on a small island is a great mix of driving magic without any consequences.

I'm looking forward to community and in house mad maps like the grid with challenges and courses filled with traps and trials that you need to execute with the surprisingly effective driving model.  Keep this in mind.  DO NOT try to use a keyboard.  It's hard enough to try to get used to the steering sensetivity with an xbox controller, but on the same note, it's a sensetivity that is needed to accomadate the full usage of the steering model.

The mods and community made parts of the game keep it interesting, while the first party models and tracks are still equal, if not slightly better in quality. (Exclusing some of the mods that plainly don't work)

One thing i've found myself doing with this game is trying to drive while watching or listening to a horror video or something that would distract me.  It helps me focus.

I want to see more crazy hotwheels like tracks like the short track on the grid test that has you drive nearly sideways without flying off the track.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I purchased Beam NG Drive before it arrived on Steam (found out about it through Greenlight. I know, crazy right?).

Not only is this game gorgeous to look at, but the realism is some of the best I've seen in any driving game (Next Car Game being a close contender). I've not played any of the modifications or tinkered with the models, but from a playability point of view it's perfect.

I thoroughly recommend you play it with a controller. I found controlling vehicles quite difficult with keyboard and mouse, especially acceleration. Perhaps I'm doing something wrong, but I found I have far better control over the vehicle than I did with keyboard.

Despite just being a sandbox driving simulator (so, no career mode, no races), it is ever so impressive, and I'm really looking forward to the career mode and multiplayer.

This game. This god damn game.

I have had this game for around 2 years, give or take a few months, and I have got my money back 10 fold. I have downloaded more mods than you can shake a giant stick at and never found it boring. With the steam release I have been more than impressed with the content, everything seems to be completely stable and one of the most beautiful games to look at, not only graphically but also physically. I have been so impressed with this game I have even bought it twice! When I lost my account a while back, I decided that I should help the developers out a bit and just buy it again! There are games like Wreckfest, which i own, but I have never seen content being added this fast and with this quality. Just buy this game. I would of recommended it more at it's old price, £9.99, but still at £18.99 it's still worth every penny. You may not like this game, you may not like it at it's current state, but just give it a go. Steam have refunds now so you can return it if it really isn't your thing, but I would recommend keeping it for a while just to see where it is going. I would also sign up to the forums of BeamNG, they have a really great community that I am proud to call myself part of. This game is going to places you cant even imagine. Get along for the ride.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me start off this review by saying I've been following BeamNG since 2012 and bought as soon as the initial release happened in 2013. The dev team has been amazing in supporting and updating the game.

Pros:
Amazing physics, detailed car design, helpful dev team. The maps are absolutely beautiful also.

Cons:
The engine is a small bit unoptimized, but the dev team is working on it. Also, sometimes there is a while between updates but the past few have been very timely, and it seems a lot of background work is behind us.

All-in-all I recommend this game, though it might not be for everyone. A majority of the game right now is a free-roam crashing simulator, though the devs have added a good many situations and races.

Also, this is a state of the art engine. You'll need a fast CPU, and sadly AMD has an architecture stuck in the past. More cores do help, but your AMD will need to be clocked a fair bit higher than usual to keep the FPS other games do. A modern (4+ series) Intel needs about 3.4Ghz to play most of the cars, to keep even the most intensive at 60+fps you'll need 4.0Ghz. Like I said though the engine is being optimized.

On the GPU side you can keep solid 60fps on medium with a 280x, and high will keep you mostly 60 but sometimes into the lower 50s. If you max the game with PostFX and reflections it will drag a 280x into the 20fps range and even a 290x has issues keeping up. This hasn't been as much of an issue until this update, so I'll update if it changes again.

TL;DR smashy, you need a good computer. I rate 10/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been playing this game for quite some time, months before this early access release on steam. I have to say, as a game in and of itself, it isn't great, but the destruction is very satisfying, and it is VERY fun to play around with different things. There are also plenty of mods on the internet, so you can add content, although it is not always stable.

With that being said, I think this game should be bought because of the technology, and the possible implications of these same soft body physics in future games. If they really get this right, I think we could have some really incredible racing sims among other things. Don't get me wrong, though, I really do enjoy playing the game in its current state, but I think you should buy it for the possibility of some amazing games in the future with similar soft-body collision physics.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*Updated at Steam Release*

This game is probably my favorite driving game of all time. Hands down. See how many hours I've played it? And that's just from Steam Experimental Release to now. I probably had 75-100 more hours before that.

The game runs beautifully, and simulates perfectly. If you are deciding whether or not to buy this, let me give you the REAL pros and cons.

PROS:
- Large Community online, creating new vehicles, terrains, etc
- Many vehicles already in-game that work flawlessly
- Physics to the extreme, you feel every bump, and so does your car.
- The map quality is phenomenal.
- Customization is fun to mess with.
- Built in terrain editor!
- You won't get bored. You can drift, you can race, you can crash test, and it never ends.

CONS:
- Requires a BEEFY graphics card and processor to run on higher settings. Don't try running Lighting Quality any higher than Lowest without a dedicated graphics card.
- Vehicle customization could be taken further, with more possible parts for each car.
- A keyboard isn't much fun. Logitech G27 Master Race.
- BEWARE RUSSIAN MODS FOR THIS GAME.

I have an Intel i7-3770S with Intel HD 4000 Graphics, and I run the game with Mesh/Texture Quality on Normal and Lighting/Shadow Quality on Lowest and get good fps all around. This game takes a lot to run, which is understandable.

OVERALL:

Buy the game. It's worth whatever you pay for it. The game is only going to get better, so why not get it now?
IT IS WORTH EVERY CENT YOU PAY. I SWEAR.
If you are looking for the ultimate crash testing, car smashing, racing, drifting, customizing, community-involved car game out there, it's this.


Note: This game is much more enjoyable with a racing/steering wheel or controller for turning movements. I personally use a Logitech G27, and it is so worth it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Right now BeamNG has a great physics engine going for it, but not much else. Slow motion crashing is surprisingly entertaining though, and I've sunk a good few hours just smashing stuff up.

However, a lot of potential is taken away by the extremely dodgy car and camera controls. Camera in the game tends to drift in the exact opposite direction you want it to go, forcing you to constantly hold down the right mouse button to control it. Cars don't seem to have any grip on road surfaces and slide around uncontrollably if you choose to drive faster than a granny on her way to shop groceries. In short, the cars don't drive well and you will fly off the road if you go faster than 40mph....which DOES look very nice, but you'll have to weight that against there being literally nothing else in the game that works, as of now.

It's still early in development, so only buy it now if you really enjoy soft body physics, otherwise wait for more features and improvements on the existing ones.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have had this game since before it came onto steam,  back then the developement was pretty slow with only one a team of around 8,  since, the team has grown heaps, the developement of vehcles has picked up hugely,

Along with the official content there is plenty of mods, though I can't say most modding of this game is easy due to the complexity of its soft body physics engine, when you get your head around it, its fun to ♥♥♥♥ about with the cares like put really wind wheels on a impressa equivelent vehicle, add a huge wing and give it an rediculiously powered motor.

But by far the best is the soft body physics which comtines to improve, the satisfying ability to know  that the stunt you just did was probably bloody accurate, and when you just feel like wrecking cars or watching your car crumple when u drive far to fast.

This game has capiblities far beyond cars, it'll be interesting what the future holds for a physics engine like this.

only problem for most people as there is little to no campain, with only a few vanila senarios, which are check point races, this will be built on later but its sill early in developement.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

NOT AVAILABLE FOR MAC OS X, LINUX or STEAMOS, and it REQUIRES A POWERFUL COMPUTER. If you don't think your computer can run BeamNG.Drive, download the demo (available on the BeamNG.Drive website) or just don't buy the game at all. Please do not waste your money and ♥♥♥♥♥ on the community forums, thanks ~

Since it's been a year, I figured I'd update my review. BeamNG.Drive is a highly accurate vehicle tech demo, featuring extremely realistic soft-body damage. While it was initially nothing fantastic in the graphics department, a few updates before the early access release certainly bumped up the graphics an sizable amount. I was blown away by the realtime reflections and the subtle lighting changes are a welcome inclusion as well. Be warned though, as you're going to need a powerful computer to play BeamNG.Drive. The demo itself is certainly more optimized than it once was, but you're still going to need a powerful CPU and a Great GPU to get the most out of BeamNG.Drive

There are certain objectives in the newest update that adds a bit more of a goal to the game, but there is also a sandbox mode, appropriately called Free Roam." If you loved playing with the swing set glitch in Grand Theft Auto 4
date: you're going to love this. (BeamNG is also planning on adding a campaign to the demo as well (at which I'll officially refer to BNG.D as a game).\n\nIt's finally available for purchase through Steam
recommended: and all updates are provided through Steam as well (this seems obvious
voteText: before the game was even on Steam
helpfulPercent: there wasn't an update method besides direct download
votesHelpful: and that was later to be upgraded with a proprietary updater. The addition of Steam updates is a lot more convenient.)\n\nOverall
votesTotal: there is something hypnotic about the game; crashing the same car into the same ramps and walls over and over again should get boring really quickly
votesFunny: and yet it doesn't. I have played this demo more than anything else on Steam
commentsCount: and I personally hate car and racing games. Go figure."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let me tell you a story.
When I was very young the darker side of my mind was very interested in cars crashing into each other. I thought it was so cool to see to cars slamming into each other and fly across the road. I was 5.
During that phase I kept looking for a video game that would let me do that. All I found were animations, or unrealistic games.
Later on, about a year ago, I saw GMOD on sale and decided to buy it, thinking it would suit my needs. I didn't.
I was so dissapointed. Would I ever find what I was looking for?
A few months later, I saw BeamNg through the corner of my eye on youtube and went to check it out.
I thought it was beautiful. Within a few weeks of that moment I had owned the game.
So, in conclusion, thank you BeamNg.Drive. You have fufilled my crazy childhood dreams(even though I am still a kid) by making an awesome game which is hours of fun.

Now, on to the good stuff!
PROS:
Everything above
Super Realistic
fully Modable
CONS:
You NEED a TURBO POWERFUL computer(I mean it when I say that) to run this game. I had to buy a $100 GTX 750 Graphics card to increase the preformance from 5-15 to 40-55 FPS. It STILL runs a little slow.

Overall, this is the ultimate car game. Get it. GET IT NOW.
10.5/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In the nearly two years I've had this game, long before you could buy it on Steam, I've seen a tremendous amount of growth and development. BeamNG.drive offers a unique sandbox experience in which you can choose from various maps and vehicles, enjoy their detail, and the exquisite damage physics. I have split this review into two categories, gameplay and performance.

Gameplay: The game offers a fantastic sandbox experience, but also a scenario mode where you can play scenarious on different maps. Maps and vehicles are very unique and detailed. Maps are beautifully textured. Vehicles have super-realistic damage physics, the most realistic out there in my opinion. Cars have different variants, you can swap parts, change the color, etc. They also have very high quality textures, reflections, and working interiors. BeamNG involves either driving random cars on random maps, or doing scenarios, but the possibilities are endless.

Performance: Before the recent 5.4.0 update, performance wasn't that great. For me, I didn't mind because I loved the game. But after this update, performance has increased by nearly 50%. Maps that would run at 15 fps now run at a silky smooth 40-50. Great job devs! Keep up the great work!

I may add to this review later, but overall I would recommend this game to someone looking for a good sandbox experience, admires realistic looking cars, terrains, and physics.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is just one thing for now: a Sandbox Not a racing, game, not a rally game, a SANDBOX. But nvertheless, it is amazing. You have a wide range of vehicles, MODS, world editor, ultra realistic physics. The game also looks very good. Better than some games that are complete. It is optimised very well, haven't crashed once. But beware though. You need a beefy cpu. At least a pentium g3258(overclocked). I would not be too worried though if you have even a q6600 because any quad core would handle this game pretty well. Even an old one. For the RAM, 4gb is enough but I recommend 8gb for the full experience. For the gpu even a basic dedicated one would do. But as I said, DEDICATED.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I purchased Beam NG Drive before it arrived on Steam (found out about it through Greenlight. I know, crazy right?).

Not only is this game gorgeous to look at, but the realism is some of the best I've seen in any driving game (Next Car Game being a close contender). I've not played any of the modifications or tinkered with the models, but from a playability point of view it's perfect.

I thoroughly recommend you play it with a controller. I found controlling vehicles quite difficult with keyboard and mouse, especially acceleration. Perhaps I'm doing something wrong, but I found I have far better control over the vehicle than I did with keyboard.

Despite just being a sandbox driving simulator (so, no career mode, no races), it is ever so impressive, and I'm really looking forward to the career mode and multiplayer.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAt the moment, being in early access, i don't feel compelled to play the game for a few hours at a stretch, but it's nice to dip into now and again. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I know this may sound strange but I actually had to refund this game as my sound card did not seem to like the game or vice versa. It's a heavy game as well, even with my PC equipped with a 4790K and a GTX 970 I had FPS drops. The main reason I had to refund though was due to the sound being strangely intermittent, it would warp if that makes sense.

Overall though I really love this game and if your PC can handle it and you love physics based shenanigans, buy it! I may have had issues with it but I really loved the game even though the issues were extremely distracting. Hopefully you will not suffer the same issues as myself and in the future, I am definitely going to be giving this game another chance because it is absolutely awesome!

I just wish I hadn't had to have refunded it because this game deserves all the support it can get!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

TrackIR support (just added) and dialing in the FFB has really brought the immersion to the next level. The game is also running very, very smoothly with very low input latency. Performance is easily 2x over what it was a year ago, let alone when they first put the tech demo on their website,

Using high and low filtering at 30, slightly increased max FFB and overall ffb strengths and 600 sampling. Each car feels believably unique, even each variant. Right now, I consider the FFB to be excellent, better than games like dirt rally and iracing.

The cement mixer is so much more immursive and alive than any ETS2+ trucks.


The devs have consistently worked away at all core issues and have really made a pretty special simulator.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBeamng.Drive is the most realistic vehicle simulator to date. The crashes are ultra realistic, the damage is ultra realistic, and the physics are ultra realistic. And don't let the graphics card requirements turn you down, because this game really doesn't need that great of a card to run at max graphics settings. I'm running it maxed out at 60+ fps on my Gtx 560 ti 2gb phantom, so no need to buy yourself a Gtx 670 for this game. This game runs great on my pc, but the framerate drops to around 20-40 with 5 cars on screen at the same time, because the game still needs some optimizations. The more cars on screen, the more processor power your pc needs, because each vehicle is extremely highly detailed, and has lots of deformation points and breakables. Ever single vehicle is very advanced and detailed, so you need a very good cpu at the moment if you want to play with 5+ cars on screen. I have an Intel core I5-3470 3.20GHz quad core cpu, and it can handle around 5 cars on screen at once with playable framerates. They said they are gonna improve framerates later on. They want to make 7 cars on screen at once run smoothly on a mid range processor, so the cpu requirements will get lower with the updates. Another awesome thing about this game is all the maps and cars you can download for free. You can also make maps and vehicles and upload them to beamng's website for others to download. It's a lot of fun, and you can do anything vehicle related you've always wanted to do with no limitations! The game's map editor is also very easy to use once you get used to it. You can create cutom objects and buildings for the map editor too by using other programs like sketchup and importing your creations to beamng's editor. It is fairly simple and easy to do. Just watch a tutorial video or two, and you can make maps with ease. Sorry for the long post, I just needed to tell you if you feel the game lacks content, you can create your own content or download content for it that other people created. The game also gets updates, since it's still work in progress, so even if you don't download or make content for the game, you will still have a great time, although I reccomend downloading others's creations and making your own stuff for the game, because it makes the game more fun. This game is very realistic and very fun at the same time. Your car can even run out of fuel, but don't worry about filling up every 2 minutes, because it takes as long as in real life for the cars in this game to run out of fuel. Besides, you'll probably wreck the car before you can get a chance to run out of fuel, since one hard crash can pretty much total your vehicle. This game is a lot of fun, and very realistic at the same time. 10 out of 10. The perfect vehicle simulator.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Everyone who likes cars or realistic physics should buy this game/simulator instantly.

Positiv:

-Many community mods on the BeamNG forum
-Very realistic physics engine
-Easily modded
-Ingame map editor
-Awesome developers

Negativ:
(Bare in mind that this game/simulator is in alpha)

-Very few nasty bugs/glitches

Neutral:

-The game/simulator is quite low spec PC friendly in terms of it settings.
So if you have a low spec PC, I recommend to turn off postFX in the settings.
-Need some sort of controller/steering wheel for the best driving experience
(I have no problem driving with the keyboard)

Conclusion:

This game/simulator may be in alpha but it is definitely worth it. It can only get better.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played beamng offline quite a lot
This review will be about what you need and should expect from the game/simulator
1. This is a extremely demanding simulator. This isn't because it is horribly optimized but because of the calculations your Pc has to make. One example of this is spawning in a vehicle that has 4000 beams. You may be thinking 4000 beams that's nothing" you are simulating 4000 beams but it's 2000 times every second 4000X2000 = 8
recommended:
000 calculations I have a quad core 3.2 ghz processor it runs this perfectly fine
2. If you aren't someone that can stand repetition this isn't for you. You repeat things alot.....well sort of. You do crash over and over but how you crash is what changes. You could do a vertical jump at 60 mph Hit a wall at 100mph or do a head on collision with each car going 150mph. It all depends on your mind. I've done nearly everything imaginable and I still come back to experiment.

TLDR :don't like repeating don't get this if you're not creative and want to be directed
These PC specs run it good when my gpu isn't the issue (get something better)
Built in 2015 (not the parts but assembly)
I5-4460 @ 3.2ghz 3.4ghz Max
Nvidia geforce 720 gtx 2gb
8gb 1600 mhz ram
280w power supply
1tb 7200 rpm hard drive
(Powersupply I know REPLACE IT but it is good enough)"

All around 7.5 to 8/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OKAY, rewriting review time. This game has matured so much since I've had it. I've played it daily, I've watched it grow, I've poured many hours into this game and interacted with the community. I taught myself many driving techniques with this game (with some mods so stalling a car is actually possible). This game was the exact game i've wanted since I was a little one playing Flatout 2 on my Xbox. Does it have problems? Absolutely. Do these matter? Absolutely not. I can't get enough of this game. The physics are satisfying, and feel real. I've yet to play a game that can make me cringe when I hit something as small as a trash can at low speed like this one can. The cars are unique and beautiful and every one is labored over to give it the exact characteristics of real life equivalents. They're fun, most imporantly, and I can't get enough of whipping the hatchback (Ibishu Covet) around a corner, or abusing the hell out of the Offraod version of the Pickup (Gavril D-Series). Even the level design shows detail, with maps being unique and having a variety of roads and ways to have fun, be it rallying through country in a small Japanese compact, or tearing up the streets in a souped up American Saloon, or ignoring roads and trails in a jacked-up delivery van. Yes, $24.99 may seem risky for an Early Access game, but these devs absolutely show promise. They constantly update the game, they constantly interact with their community, and I've even had conversations with some of the staff... They're great people, and they love this game like it was their child. They prioritize keeping the game updated, fresh with fun and new stuff, and fixing major problems. I can't tell anyone what to do with their money, but I can more than recommend buying this game to anyone who consults me on it. Please do yourself this favor.

Quick notes about this game:
-ABSOLUTELY USE A CONTROLLER OR WHEEL, keyboard is still fun but is nowhere near as great as the former two options
-Fairly demanding, don't expect to have 10-car derbies with a laptop. Even my i7 4790k and GTX 980 only do 9 cars at once on certain levels before it becomes difficult to play
-Bear with the devs, there are problems that pop up... With this in mind, do go to the official BeamNG forums for help, the community and devs always find solutions to these problems

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Beamng Is a one of a kind game, its a game that was built specifically to simulate crashing physics wiht vehicles.

Pros
-Graphics are nice
-Gameplay is smooth
-Amazing Physics
-Content
-Specifics on whats damaged
-Realistic Engine Heating
-Mods
-Updates
-Sounds
-Ability to go into slow motion
-level editor

Cons
-Its not the worst with optimization, but is a hard game to run due to everything it has to offer.
-Not much to do

All of the cons are to be expected in an early access title. If you are wishing to buy a bug free and fully complete game, you are looking in the wrong category. Beamng is really moving in the right derection. Almost every month there is a major update, and the game has yet to disappoint me. Its really hard to come up with cons about a game that I really enjoy. I could add to the pros list for days, but I sat here for like 10 minutes just to find those 2 cons. So that should really tell you something. I do recommend this game.

If you would like, feel free to add me on Steam.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

BeamNG.drive is a physics simulation from some of the same people that brought you Rigs of Rods[www.rigsofrods.com] and some of its top quality mods. When comparing the two, it is evident that lots of lessons have been learnt and that each developer has improved greatly in their respective field, resulting in state of the art physics that simulate every single part of a vehicle/object with almost true to life accuracy (with accuracy and efficiency being improved as development goes on), near perfectly modelled fictional vehicles that each represent a certain type of vehicle, resulting in a diverse, albeit small selection (current vehicle list, [wiki.beamng.com] in-dev, concept vehicles list[wiki.beamng.com]) , and fantastic locations[wiki.beamng.com] that push the graphics engine, Torque3D[www.garagegames.com] to its limits. Currently, the Small Island map is my personal favourite mainly due to the recent overhaul that added so many little details. I hope Dry Rock is also updated in a similar fashion.

In terms of gameplay, it is currently just a sandbox, but a planned update will bring timed races (no advanced AI YET) and online leaderboards to the table as the first step in the direction of given gameplay, but I still think the sandbox will be where the majority of the entertainment is.

The game is very moddable, all sorts of vehicles can be added, including helicopters and planes, levels can be created in the in-game level editor, and LUA files that make up quite a lot of the code can be freely edited to tailor your experience to your liking or even add features. A feature that I quite like that has been created by the community with LUA scripting has been changing the engine sound depending on the vehicle that is being used. Mods should only be downloaded from the official forum's showroom and downloading from anywhere else will either leave you with some kind of malware or very disappointed.

The current sound system is a placeholder to avoid people moaning about sound not working" really
hoursPlayed: and crash sound making up the entirety of the vehicle's vocabulary (can be modded though) and a few ambient background tracks. This will be completely redone eventually.\n\nThe vehicle's handling characteristics can be quirky at times with some seemingly random veering at very high speeds and vehicles losing friction too easily
voteText: but the physics will be continuously improved and tweaked to ensure maximum authenticity. I can see this rivalling high profile racing simulators in the future.\n\nThe game needs a fairly high end CPU (or more specifically
helpfulPercent: a CPU with fairly powerful cores) in order to run the physics smoothly. My i5 3570k can run 4 detailed vehicles smoothly
votesHelpful: but those with certain AMD CPUs may struggle. Even though they have lots of cores
votesTotal: each core is quite weak. To run the game at max graphical settings
votesFunny: a fairly powerful GPU will also be required
commentsCount:
but most semi-recent mid range video cards should be able to run it with lower settings fine. The tech demo will be updated soon so I suggest going to beamng.com and trying it out before purchasing.

I've probably sunk hundreds of hours into it so it's safe to say that I've probably got my money's worth.

I think that is all I currently have to say
column16: but I'll probably remember something else in 5 minutes.\n\nTL;DR:  Physics
column18: don't complain if your ZX Spectrum doesn't run it at 120 fps etc."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game even though it is unfinished is great even in this state,the detail of destruction is apsolutely amazing and the driving physics are almost perfect.
This game simulates the bending of metal on the car in corners,it simulates the bending and folding of tires at sudden acceleration,since the last update it even simulates the turbochargers based on their size and how they would work in real life.The stock vehicles and maps are amazingly made for this game,and the mod support is great too,so if you get bored of the realism of this game you can just download a 6000hp pickup truck and watch it tear itself apart as it is trying to travel in a straight line.

This game is not perfect,it is sometimes unstable and it can crash when least expected,also the framerate doesen't depend on your graphical settings it depends on what vehicle you are using and which map you are on,so the game's engine could use some tweaking with that,since it uses only one CPU core per vehicle,no matter if the vehicle is a three wheeled crapmobile or a eight wheeled monster truck it still gets only one core per vehicle,so make sure you check the sistem requirements before buying

Anyways, its hyper-realistic damage is rendered at (when I last checked) 1500FPS, meaning slow motion is available and darn beautiful when used during the making of 'Vancakes'.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

8/13/2014
got my alpha code in email because i had played it a while ago. last time i had played it, it was very similar, but a lot more buggy and had less content. that was probably 1-3 years ago, i cant remember. but i had only played it for an hour and got fed up with it before uninstalling it because it was so ♥♥♥♥♥♥.

NOW, it installs over steam, has longish loading times (who cares though), the controls are kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ for m+k but work if you're patient and learn to tap and feather the keys you can deal with it, and the graphics (artstyle) are fairly nice, but a little lacking contrast in the colors.

The game runs fairly well, considering how much ♥♥♥♥ is actually being drawn on screen and how the devs implemented it (see: placing a bunch of objects on screen by hand). Which means: its really nice to explore and see the sights, but you need a powerful computer to do it. I'm running a 768mb 460gtx and a first gen i7. With all graphics up to high (except the garrys mod-esqe post processing) I get about 15fps while completely stationary in a forrest. with most things on lowest or low (lowest threshold until the game looks like ♥♥♥♥ due to flat meshes and NO shading) I can get up to about 55fps.

there's a lot of pop-in for random tree areas and buildings, which isnt really a big deal but worth noting.

the car handling itself is fairly difficult, because at low speeds the cars handle alright but once you speed up, the fps chugs randomly, the cars feel like they're on ice and makes crashes/flips inevitable. It almost feels like they're trying to make you crash. This is neat for showing off your crash mechanics (which i admit are incredible, i ripped out a part of my steering on one side because i high centered over a large rock and couldnt control that wheel much) you can ctrl+r to reload your vehicle and drop five feet away, but the location drifts a little to one direction each time and you can easily be stuck in a load-loop into a wall or trees or some other obsticle with no way out except to keep hitting reload unti you come out the other side. Pretty annoying, yet..... somehow satisfying when you're free.

If I get a wheel or controller, a more powerful computer, and they keep adding content and fixing bugs, I'd say this game could be the driving sandbox (gta style raging/romping) equivalent of a walking-sim type game. There are jumps, trails, roads all around the island in grand touring style, big meadows, swamps, ponds, beaches, abandoned buildings a la ken block, and lots of things to smash your car on and have to reset. It would make a VERY nice exploration/relaxing/personal satisfaction driving sim with a high potential of adventure.

My biggest desires for adds/fixes for this game are:
1) customizable suspension and drivetrain settings to tweak
2) them to keep adding more content because I like the style they're doing it in (the offroad 4x4 stuff is REALLY nice)
3) optimizations ZOMG<---
4) better color palette (its not bad, just leaves something to be desired and feels washed out when out in the open)
6) more cars!!!
7) the handling to not be so ♥♥♥♥♥♥ (maybe this is just because im trying to control a sim driving game with a keyboard)
8) better follow-view camera
9) some extra motivation for playing it besides just screwing around (missions, characters, story, multiplayer, rpg, unlocking more content/vehicles/zones/parts/things, races, timetrials)
10) the ability to get out of the car and do other things, gta style)

Right now, the game isnt worth much if you dont like driving around irl or in gta games. I dont know much about the pacing of the dev, but Im going to go ahead and say they're slow as ♥♥♥♥.

In a few years, maybe this game will be really cool. But, until then, its very much in alpha and has been for a long time. If this is your thing, cool, if you can't entertain yourself by driving around and exploring in a very buggy game, steer clear of this one for now.

sound: 6/10 (nice directionality, but all cars sound the same and stuff isnt very dynamic. great ambience. not too buggy.)
graphics: 7.5/10 (if you could get it all to run at a decent fps with no pop-in or stuttering, it would be VERY nice.)
menus: 5/10 (lots of options, yet somehow still lacking options. average to bad organization. very ♥♥♥♥♥♥ loading times.)
art: 7/10 (cool, sterile, matrix like maps. really cool idea of loading up a world feel. surprisingly immersive. cozy".)
playability: 4/10 (sub average. frustrating experience driving around on the roads
date: but very pleasurable 4x4 experiences.)\nvalue: 6/10 (the ability to drop in with no strings is a double edged sword. easy to get into
recommended: easy to get out of once it crashes.)\n\noverall: 6/10 (its a slightly above average early access game with a lot of potential. whether or not the devs will realize their own potential is a whole different story. I'm going to learn towards "yes
hoursPlayed: but not in any near time in the future if ever")\n\n"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI've had this game for a while now and I have been thoroughly impressed with it. Crashing cars in any game is fun but in the case of BeamNG.drive it is outrageously fantastic. The game has an incredible physics engine and beautiful graphic detail which delivers some of the most realistic gameplay I have ever come across in a driving simulator. The variety of vehicles within the game is also very well rounded and with the different mods that can be added on to the game, that variety extends even further. The game isn't without it's flaws which is to be expected with an early access title, but as it is right now, BeamNG.Drive is a great game and is definitely worth a play.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you buy this don't expect much. As with most early access. Or you will be disappointed.

I can't say yea get this game. But if you want a crash simulator then maybe.
The driving physics are just terrible. It does map to a wheel now. So at least it has that now.

It works with an xbox 360 controller fairly well.

If you total your car you may have to restart the game, because it just spawns the other car right next to it. If there are trees or other cars you will spawn inside them.

The game is not very  playable as it is. Its ok for about 10 minutes or so at a time, but after that it crashes, or you will just get bored.

I am not sure the developers mission. The progress has been really slow since I got the game. I expect in the end for the game to be playable, and hopefully at the sim level for driving experience. As for what kind of sim it will be, I am guessing a crash sim involving all terrain situations.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Concept is very good, but developers are not very nice or good. BeamNG is all about crashing, crash physics and visual damage is 99% real-life like. Here is my BeamNG vs Real Life comparison video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JsQsAzlEPNw

Very accurate, but developers constantly break things and try adding nonsense that nobody cares about. This game is not about driving or racing, if you want a racing game, play Next Car Game Wreckfest or Need for Speed series, BeamNG is all about crash physics. Developers need to add demolition derby option.
99% of people who play this game, play it for the damage and crashes.

I do recommend this game, but just be warned ... game is buggy and glitchy and developer support is very poor.
2 years ago, developers PROMISED to have demoltion derby events out, now 2 years later (almost 3), they have removed the option to have basic demolition derby, very disappointed in this.

Don't get me wrong, game is cool and concept is unique, but progress is slow and developers do what they want to do, they do not listen to the community at all.
A good game is not a game where developers do what they want, but a game where developers listen to majority of their customers and fulfill their ideas.

Serious Review:

PHYSICS:
Awesome. Spectacular.
This game runs on an engine called Torque3D, and based off my time that I've spent enjoying this game, it's really good. The crash physics are awesome. The suspension simulation, the physics, everything, is perfect.

CONTROLS:
Has decent wheel support. I think the forcefeedback could be improved, but beyond that, it's awesome.
The handling of the cars is just right. Perhaps not the best in the world, but it works really well. The cars feel heavy, the steering of cars isn't too arcade-like, it feels just right.

GRAPHICS:
Pretty. Moving on.

MODDING:
It's very easy to do. The developers have made a mod section of their website to easily find mods instead of using the forums. I guess it works, but I don't know why they had to put more load on their servers when they could have simply created a steam workshop.

Other than that, you'll never need anything more than winrar it seems. All I ever need to do is just drop files into a folder named mods".
It's incredible.



It's a fun game to play. Worth the money."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game horrifies me, utterly and terribly. I'm on the last of a fifteen checkpoint trial. I slide around a corner doing twenty-five. My eyes widen in terror when I see a tree clip my back wheel, bending it all to hell and making the race impossible to finish. *presses R" to restart for the tenth time*

Let me just say
date: this game is hard. Your car will feel slow and clunky and will squash like a bug at seemingly stupid slow speeds. It is just about as realistic in that regard as it gets. Like any racing game
recommended: there are fast and slow cars. Except they all break equally as easy
hoursPlayed: so don't think going faster is always better.\n\nAnd as for so many people saying the cars feel like they're on ice
voteText: ignore them. If you've ever driven on solid ice
helpfulPercent: you would know that you can't get going more than a few miles an hour in a decent turn before you're going sideways. A car is held in place by four little patches of rubber each about the size of your hand. Once you break sliding friction
votesHelpful: you're boned.\n\nAlso
votesTotal: for anyone turned off by the fact that this is a "crashing simulator
votesFunny:
I would also disagree. The fun is in the trials. The launching your car off a four story cube in the test world gets boring after a while. There are something like 15 ish trials right now that range from small circuits to long rallies to silly stuff like seeing if you can jump four ramps in a row or make your way down a six-hundred foot cliff. There will be a campaign mode integrated eventually.

The game encourages smart driving (knowing the limits of your car, how fast you need to enter turns, when to accelerate and when to brake). You don't need a steering wheel or pedals, but I'm sure they'd be fun.

The only issue I have with the game is its checkpoint system. First of all, they're huge and kinda ugly. Secondly, if you try to switch out your vehicle with another mid-race, it screws everything up.

I don't mind this one, but the sound is kinda awful. Engines sounds are cool, crashes are just okay, but the tire squeeling is horrible.

This game is fun for what it is already, and definitely worth the money. The devs do decent sized updates about every month now and release bug fixes several times a month to deal with whatever they broke in the patches and/or fix other small issues.

I never write reviews, but I figured this would be the one. Just goes to show how great I think this game is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game needs a lot of work (the sound is terrible at the moment, sounds like something out of a game from the 80's), but the physics and controller support are amazing!

This game is in alpha, so I am sure (hopeful) it will get better, but the promise of a game that is everything it promises is... promising :)

I look forward to seeing this game further developed into the next level of racing sim.

On a side note: the choice (or lack of choice) to use cars that are close to real, but not brand licensed works very well and unless car makers start giving away rights to their vehicles, I don't car if I am driving something with badges that are not real" (so long as a "Mustang-like" of some generation is eventually included). Looking forward to seeing a LOT more cars."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Love the game.It's a great game to play if you just want to sit back, relax, fool around on facebook and listen to music. If you have been
dreaming of a game with realistic crash damage, this is absolutely the game for you. The soft body physics are pretty well flawless unless you download a ported community created car. Most community created cars are done well though and are very fun to play with in this smash em' up car simulator. One thing I'm sad about is that there is no community workshop for this game for user created cars and maps so you have to download from their  website [www.beamng.com]. Even still, installation of community creations is very simple; just a drag and drop of a folder. There are some missions for you to play where you can drive through checkpoints and do jumps and all, but besides that, there is no objective other than what you make up. You can test your car's durability as hard as you want with this game. It gives you complete freedom of how to smash your car, always with a satisfying result and that is why recommend this game.

This is probably the most realistic driving game I've played so far.

pros:

+ Realistic Physics
+ The cars can be customised
+ Mods

cons:

- Won't work with my ps1 controllers
- Sometimes hard to add mods

suggestions:
+ Put the mods on the workshop
+ Add some more controls for when the cars is stuck
+ Split-screen local multiplayer
+ Online Multiplayer
Overall this game is great 9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has an extremely addictive personality to it allowing you as the player to interact with the physics of each and every vehicle within this game.
I well and truely reccomned this game to anyone that's interested in soft body physics of cars.
Also this game features an immaculate representation of time passing, allowing the player to unlock what is not seen by us in the event of a vehicle collision or accident because our eyes and brain can only see at 25-26 frames per second (this is why 60fps and above is good) the mechanic of this game lets you slow down time to a maximum of x100 letting you see the whole crash from start to finish with superb deformity of the cars in this stunning simulation of the soft body physics of cars there is a gravity control machanic letting you choose the gravity on a slider or by clicking the presets given which starts at the sun and finishes at pluto going though each and every plannet in our solar system there is also luna gravity too but only featuring The Moon though.
All in all this is a fornominal game and simulation and i've already clocked in 13.8 hours into this on steam but off steam its most likely embarrisingly longer because it's such an inriching and infinatly pleasing experience cars being crashed, crumpled and smoshed either by other cars or just by driving them into walls and not having to explain to insurance companies and loosing your possible future offspring's inheritance. anyway this review is definatly not bias and rambley at all and i think you should buy it for 20 quid on steam because its amazing and cool and stuff. lel

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An awesome vehicle sandbox, showcasing soft-body physics and cars built from multiple parts quite realisticly instead of just one model like in racing games. It's Red Faction for cars, with plenty to mess around with, though lacking any objective outside of short missions varying from driving routes to disabling ai vehicles, seperate from the free-roam structure that you would spend most of your time in. There are frequent updates and an interesting modding community, adding plenty of tracks and vehicles.

There are a few negatives in it's lack of objective and the mildly annoying camera, plus physics crashes, ui bugs and unresponsive controls do happen relatively often, but overall I'd still recommend it to anyone.

For Example  I can Make My Car Have No Roof   Have No Doors      No Engine:     Or Even A Frame:       There Is Also Many Different Types Of That Same part such As: Racing Steering Wheel:    Regular Steering Wheel:   Offroad Tires: Or Regular Stock Tires:   Every Single Part Of A Vehicle Is Simulated:  The Gauges On The dash Board:    The Petals Such As The Gas Petal And Brake Also Clutch:   The Shocks/Springs  The Suspension:     The Engine:     The Head And Tail Lights:      And Remember Its All Destructible!    Soft Body Physics;    The Devs Are Also Really Active To The community Of The Game.  They Have furoms Where You Can Speak With Them: Report Bugs And More:   They Also Have AMAZING!   Videos Of The New Cars They Add To The Game:   I beleve the director is      Nadoex1:    They are Really Well Made Tho:    You Can Downlaod Maps Mods Cars And Helicopters Planes And More:       The Devs Update Very Commonly And They Add/Fix Alot Of Things In There Main Updates:   In Version 0.5.0 They Added Fire  And Lots Of New Stuff:   The Devs Are Working Hard And I Respect them:  They Are Very Open Minded:   I Hope One Day To See BeamNG.drive's  Full Realease:      Pros: AMAZING! Soft Body Physics:        Regular Updates:    Realistic Part Configuration System:        Great Graphics:   Heavily Moddable:   Lots Of Vehicles In The Game:  Variety Of Detailed Maps:    Work In Progress AI That Can Drive On Roads..Mostly On Stock Maps:       In Game Editor: And Last But Not Least A Hard Working Dev Crew Good Job Devs!      Cons: NONE At ALL !:   I Perseninoly Give BeamNG 10/10 I recommend It To Anyone Who Is Enterested In A Game About Cars: Crashing:  Physics: Fun: And Racing W.I.P:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright. So...

Game reccomended system requirements:

OS: Windows 8 64 Bit
Processor: High-end Intel i5/i7 or High-end AMD 6 Core or better
Memory: 8 GB RAM
Graphics: GTX 780
DirectX: Version 11
Storage: 4 GB available space

My computer:

OS: Windows 8, 64 bit
Processor: Intel i5
Memory: 6 GB ram (5.82 Usable) (While this is lower than the reccomended, it is way above the required, and dosen't excuse the fact that this game runs like a potato)
Graphics: GTX 780
DirectX: Version 11
Storage: 312 GB available space

I should be able to run the game fine. right?

Nah. Instead, it runs like an old guy on an escalator.

Do NOT buy this game, unless your system specs are at least twice as high as the reccomended numbers.

As for the game itself, it's okay. A variety of cars and trucks. Pretty good soft-body physics.

Buy it when on sale. Not quite worth $25.

6.5/10

Try Flatout Ultimate Carnage, if you like these types of games. (It also runs better)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An awesome vehicle sandbox, showcasing soft-body physics and cars built from multiple parts quite realisticly instead of just one model like in racing games. It's Red Faction for cars, with plenty to mess around with, though lacking any objective outside of short missions varying from driving routes to disabling ai vehicles, seperate from the free-roam structure that you would spend most of your time in. There are frequent updates and an interesting modding community, adding plenty of tracks and vehicles.

There are a few negatives in it's lack of objective and the mildly annoying camera, plus physics crashes, ui bugs and unresponsive controls do happen relatively often, but overall I'd still recommend it to anyone.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Nobody can say should you buy this or not because first of all its a early access still so the game isnt finished yet but hope it will be soon.

PROS

- Crashing!  Crashing seems really good if you have seen real crashes

- Cars. You can choose in Early access many cars not just few like many other sandbox games gives us.

- Car Tuning.  In some cars you can tune them a lot! it makes it really interesting :)

NEGATIVE

- Driving :(   Sadly the driving isnt really good and you lose your grip REALLY easily. driving in a normal road 60km/h and wosh you are in the tree next time..

- Scenarios.  Scenarios becomes negative just because the driving.. some Scenarios are really fun and cool but when you get a road what is jumpy as hell.. you just cannot keep your car straight it just keeps going to the tree in no time.

- AI.  The bot driver mostly these Scenarios where you are a Police this AI can be smart or just really really stupid.. there isnt much where you versus bot is but I hope there will be more..

Yeah this game isnt now or never will be made for Racing or do missions etc but I hope :) its a good start and I believe it will be good in the end..

7/10 would cry more but tired

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hi Everyone! I promised one of the people at BeamNG I would give an honest review of BeamNG.drive an honest Review so here it goes. As you can see I have put 37.2 hrs to date actually playing the game but what you can't see is the 100 or so hours I have used in resurching diffrent aspects of the game as well and here is what I have found. For those of you that don't mind doing the reasurch involved and have a better then basic understanding of computer modeling and softwear This could be the best game in the world to own but if your like me and just want to do all the things you've seen on videos and have a imagination that keeps you up nights trying new things but can't quite figure out how to make it happen then this can be quite frustraiting at times and your not alone. Little things like picking up a car and placing it into a position all the way up to building new ramps or objects to run into or over can be quite nervracking if you don'tknow or can't figure out the map editor. Many of the YouTube video's show some pretty awsome stunts but even fewer of them will tell you how it's done. I have spen't hours looking for good tutorials but unfortunetly they are few and far between and they are often incomplete or just plain outdated and don't work withe the ever increasing number of updates. Unfortunetly when using the map editor or any other editor (they have a list) if you don't know what you are doing and are unfortunite enough to know how to get rid of it. You may find the same problem the next time you load the very same map So if there is anything I may suggest is you Back up the game the very first time you load it as well as copy all your mods to a outside folder so they can all be added at the same time should you need to reinstall the game. This was a nother lesson I leaned the hard way.
On the brighter side this game isn't finnished not yet and BeamNG.drive is constantly being worked on by a group of dedicated and carring induviduals from diffrent countries around the world and I've been around long enough to know that anything ever built good takes a long time to perfect. There is so many cool parts of this game and if they keep going at it with the dedication they have exhibited thus far I haven't a doubt someday thier are going to be even larger groups of gammers playing BeamNG.drive and withing they had it there game library a lot sooner. Even if your just an old Hightech junkie redneck like me It's still a lot of fun. As for you You Tubers that like to make BeamNG.drive videos when your showing something that might be new to some of us,  It's ok to show how you did it, not everyone knows what you might know so please pass the info along. THX

Unfortunetly when using the map editor or any other editor (they have a list) if you don't know what you are doing and are unfortunite enough to know how to get rid of it. You may find the same problem the next time you load the very same map So if there is anything I may suggest is you Back up the game the very first time you load it as well as copy all your mods to a outside folder so they can all be added at the same time should you need to reinstall the game. This was a nother lesson I leaned the hard way.
On the brighter side this game isn't finnished not yet and BeamNG.drive is constantly being worked on by a group of dedicated and carring induviduals from diffrent countries around the world and I've been around long enough to know that anything ever built good takes a long time to perfect. There is so many cool parts of this game and if they keep going at it with the dedication they have exhibited thus far I haven't a doubt someday thier are going to be even larger groups of gammers playing BeamNG.drive and withing they had it there game library a lot sooner. Even if your just an old Hightech junkie redneck like me It's still a lot of fun. As for you You Tubers that like to make BeamNG.drive videos when your showing something that might be new to some of us,  It's ok to show how you did it, not everyone knows what you might know so please pass the info along. THX

Hi Everyone! I promised one of the people at BeamNG I would give an honest review of BeamNG.drive an honest Review so here it goes. As you can see I have put 37.2 hrs to date actually playing the game but what you can't see is the 100 or so hours I have used in resurching diffrent aspects of the game as well and here is what I have found. For those of you that don't mind doing the reasurch involved and have a better then basic understanding of computer modeling and softwear This could be the best game in the world to own but if your like me and just want to do all the things you've seen on videos and have a imagination that keeps you up nights trying new things but can't quite figure out how to make it happen then this can be quite frustraiting at times and your not alone. Little things like picking up a car and placing it into a position all the way up to building new ramps or objects to run into or over can be quite nervracking if you don'tknow or can't figure out the map editor. Many of the YouTube video's show some pretty awsome stunts but even fewer of them will tell you how it's done. I have spen't hours looking for good tutorials but unfortunetly they are few and far between and they are often incomplete or just plain outdated and don't work withe the ever increasing number of updates. Unfortunetly when using the map editor or any other editor (they have a list) if you don't know what you are doing and are unfortunite enough to know how to get rid of it. You may find the same problem the next time you load the very same map So if there is anything I may suggest is you Back up the game the very first time you load it as well as copy all your mods to a outside folder so they can all be added at the same time should you need to reinstall the game. This was a nother lesson I leaned the hard way.
On the brighter side this game isn't finnished not yet and BeamNG.drive is constantly being worked on by a group of dedicated and carring induviduals from diffrent countries around the world and I've been around long enough to know that anything ever built good takes a long time to perfect. There is so many cool parts of this game and if they keep going at it with the dedication they have exhibited thus far I haven't a doubt someday thier are going to be even larger groups of gammers playing BeamNG.drive and withing they had it there game library a lot sooner. Even if your just an old Hightech junkie redneck like me It's still a lot of fun. As for you You Tubers that like to make BeamNG.drive videos when your showing something that might be new to some of us,  It's ok to show how you did it, not everyone knows what you might know so please pass the info along.
